text: TANAKA (50) and old SAKAMOTO (late 60s but seems older; * weathered, bent) confer in whispers. SAKAMOTO’s wife, MOT (40) reclines, wrapped in a quilt. She is frail, her face etched with pain. She opens her eyes briefly to drink a medicinal tea: they are a silver color. In secret, her daughters CBIYO (9, clean-limbed, delicate and SATSU (15, slow, earthy) listen behind a make-shift screen. The TWO MEN continue in JAPANESE: *
Have you made any provision for your daughters?
(his head bowed in shame) * I've nothing left. Nothing. * Without understanding Japanese, we still comprehend the g situation. *
Satsu grips little Chiyo‘s hand tightly:
You're not young. Like this house. One good storm could carry you off. Satsu turns away, she cannot bear to hear more. But littl Chiye desperately presses her ear against the “wall's
I've nothing left to offer them but my prayers.
Let me take them; I will make arrangements~. Sakomoto eyes him with both alarm and regret.
I could never—-.
Any life would be better than the one that awaits them here.
uw
Abrupt awakening. In darkness Satsu and Chiyo are rudely roused. Sakamoto’s weathered old face distorted by the li of his oil lamp. :
(in Japanese) Quiet!

In the pelting rain, Sakamoto grimly lifts Chiyo into Tanaka's wooden cart, handing her to Satsu. in front, Tan takes the reins of the OX. Sakamoto lifts his lantern for final look as the cart pulls away. His old eyes fill with tears. . In Chiyo’s face, rainwater and sorrow stream together dow her face. The softly accented VOICE of 4 mature woman narrates in ENGLISH: ~ SAYURT’S VOICE A story like mine should never be told. Chiyo is jolted about in the back as Tanaka's fish-staine cart rattles over rough road. . SAYURI'S VOICE (cont‘d) For my world is as forbidden as it is fragile; without it’s mysteries, it cannot survive. Low-hanging branches whip the cart; Satsu pulis Chiyo clo to guard her from them. Tanaka urges the oxen onward. SAYURI'S VOICE (cont’d) My family lived in a tipsy house in a tiny village called Yoroido on the Sea of Japan. When I was born, my father was already old. My mother said he was like wood, as rooted to the earth as an old Sakura tree. But she and I were like water. Water doesn't stay in one place; it flows quickly-- The heavy oak wheels carve grooves through the mud. in th driving rain, they fill with water, which courses in rivu across the ground, tiny rivers. SAYURI'S VOICE {cont‘d) -and when something blocks the way, water makes a new path. A RIVULET veers to one side rather than pass over a stone ee eH
ee oe eH ee ee
Ae EH
Chill gray light. A coal-fired TRAIN ENGINE--like a great black DRAGON, belching smoke, with one malevolent white e idles on the platform. [Japanese sign: “Senzuru"].

I certainly wasn’t born to the life of a geisha. MEN load mailbacs, boxes of dried fish, sacks of rice. Fe passengers are boarding. On the platform weits MR. BEKKU (middle-aged, impersonal, coid). SAYURI‘S VOICE (cont'd) Like so much in my strange life, 1 was carried there, by the current. Tanaka greets Bekku, leaving Satsu and Chiyo huddled clos each other, shivering in their bare feet. They hold hande tightly. Tanaka makes the girls stand in front of Bekku:

Bow to Mr. Bekku. Satsu bows obedientiy, but Chiyo is too frightened; she j Stares at Bekku, dumbstruck. His heori (jacket) & kimono of smooth silk; his hands as soft as a woman's. TANAKA {cont ‘d) You too. Shaken out of her stupor, Chiyo bows. When she raises her head, Bekku notices her haunting silver eyes.
Hm. Curious eyes.
I have my mother’s eyes.
(to Tanaka) What are their names?
She's Chiyo. Her eister is Satsu. Bekku turns to Satsu and prods her.
They're sisters? She looks like a peasant next to this little one.
Their father does not want them to be separated. , Bekku hands him an envelope and both men bow. Tanaka touc the girls reassuringly, encouraging them: TANAKA (cont'd) Be good.  10 121 12 43 14 Als 15
Gripping their elbows, Bekku propels Satsu and Chiyo into train car. Chiyo tries to twist free, calis to Tanaka:
Tanaka-san! Mr. Bekku jerks Chiyo on board.
(calling after them) Meta yo!.
The TRAIN winds through a megnificent vista of hilis and trees still stark with winter.

Sparks fly from the train brakes, and the SOUND of metal wheels scream agains metal tracks. INT./EXT. TRAIN STATION - MIYAKO. EVENING. [WINTER]. Bekku and hie two tiny warde disembark from the train. He ushers them through the bedlam of PASSENGERS, TRAIN OFFIC and BAGGAGE RANDLERS. Bekku puts Satsu and Chiyo in the RICKSHAW. He climbs in, wedging himself between Chiyo and Satsu. 10 il 12 a3 a4 Al5 15  J. 17 EXT: RICKSHAW MOVING - STREETS OF THE HANAMACHI. MIYAKO. NIGHT. [WINTER]. Chiyo keeps peeking past the huge form of Bekku, glimpsin passing buildings and brightly-lit electrical signs. POV image: A DISTINCTIVE TORII GATE spans the entrance to huge SHRINE, flanked by rows of HUGE WHITE PAPER LANTERNS They have crossed the winding river known as the Sonogawa they’re met by a crush of BICYCLES, HORSE-DRAWN CARTS, RICKSHAWS, and AUTOMOBILES. GROUPS of MEN in Western clothes and fedoras pass by the YUKIMOTO TEAHOUSE, its wall hung with lanterns and theatr posters covered with Japanese & Chinese characters. Chiyo curiously cranes to see more but Bekku shoves her b and pins her firmly.
Narrow streets are crowded with shuttered wooden facades the silhouettes of low tiled roofs. The darkness is punctuated by a few red lanterns in the near-distance.

Sokode. The rickshaw arrives at a wooden entrance gate. Bekku pul the girls from the rickshaw. He slides open the gate. Chiyo sees a lantern hanging ove wet stone courtyard, and beyond that, the entrance into a traditional Japanese okiya. The door is open: A mysterious female SILHOUETTE glides toward Chiyo, pause Her shape moves into the light of the lantern above the p revealing: HATSUMOMO (28), in full geisha regalia: Gorgeous kimono, sensuously-upswept hair studded with dangling hair orname A mask of pearl-white make-up sets off a blood-red mouth large almond-shaped eyes rimmed with fluid black. Behind her, AUNTIE (55) strikes a flint, “flinting” Hatsu for luck; SPARKS rain upon her back.  18 Bekku pushes the girls down onto the wet ground. Hatsumom steps imperiously past in her delicate sandals and pure w tabi (gloves for the feet]. As she ‘sweeps by, Chiyo turn her face up to watch: The geisha’s fluid kimono sleeves slowly lift like dreamy silken wings. She glides away like a butterfly of the nig Auntie moves to the girls, cane in hand. She walks with a slight limp, her hip jutting forward.
These are the girls from Tanaka?
Sisters, yes, from Yoroido.
(peers at Chiyo) This one maybe. The other one, no. Bekku roughly yanks Satsu back into the rickshaw.
Hayaku. The DRIVER pulls away. Chiyo rushes into the street. Crying, Satsu reaches out for her, but Auntie captures Ch The rickshaw flies on:
Satsu!
Chiyo-chan!
Auntie slides back a door to the okiya.
Show your respect for Mother. You must not speak; I will answer for you. (calling) Okasan!

{from within) Come in!  10 Auntie pushes open ‘a shoji screen, revealing a dark room where a RADIO plays. Through spirals of smoke, Chiyo can a neatly-coiffed woman kneeling before accounting books, smoking a long traditional pipe: MOTHER (40s, business woman). Auntie grips Chiyo and whispers:
Kneel. And head down! Never look her in the face. Auntie shoves Chiyo's head down. Smoke streams from Mothe nose as she appraises the grubby child. She motions: Clos
How old are you?
She is Year of the Rooster.
Only nine? Mother makes: a dismissive sound and examines Chiyo‘’s di feet. She pulls up Chiyo’s dress to look at her straight legs; runs her thumb down Chiyo’s spine. Chiyo blurts:
Where is my sister? Auntie claps a hand over her mouth. Mother looks at Chiyo
Let me see those eyes. Auntie stares. She hadn‘t noticed before. MOTHER (cont'd) Too much water.
But Okasan, a little water is good, to guard against fire. You won’t have to worry about the okiya burning, and losing all your kimono. Mother considers this impassively. She gestures, Go on.
These country girls. Too late to send her back now.  20 11

Auntie pushes Chiyo up a step-tansu into the darkness of second floor. Chiyo notices a door ajar and peers inside. GRANNY reclines, an elderly figure with a balding crown a decayed teeth speckled with gold fillings; her skin yello and sagging. Her chin moves as she mumbles sutras under h breath. Chiyo recoils.
Mm. Yes. Granny. This used to be her okiya. Auntie leads Chiyo down a dark crooked passageway.
What happened to her skin?
(by way of explanation) Lead. That old make-up was poison. Auntie pushes Chiyo up a few small steps -- INT: MAID’S ROOM. SECOND FLOOR. NIGHT. [WINTER] 20
Keep her quiet. Mother is downstairs. -- to PUMPKIN (11, round-faced, comic.) Auntie shuts the door and Chiyo hears the bolt fall. She beats on the door
Let me go! Let me go! She weeps as Pumpkin tries to pull her away --
Shhh. Stop that. Mother will hear you; she’s got a bamboo stick.
I want my sister! Pumpkin pulls Chiyo onto her futon, and muffles her sobs the quilt.  21 12

I cried, too, at first. You know, it is easier if you just forget everything that happened before you came to the okiya. If you impress Mother, and do exactly as she says-- (beaming at the possibility) --she will send you to school to be a geisha!
A what?

A geisha. Like Hatsumomo! You will get to drink sake, and sleep until noon. PUMPKIN grins encouragingly, and sticks her chest out. Sh wears two braids, pinned to her scalp. One sticks up, jaunty, like a stem. YOUNG PUMPKIN (cont‘d) (beat) I am Pumpkin. And an apt name it is, given her hairstyle.
Where is my sister?
Probably in another okiya in the Hanamachi. {with painful clarity) Your family sold you to this house. You live here now. As this sinks in, ON CHIYO’S FACE --
Shivering, Chiyo (naked) squats on the stones near the privies, Auntie scrubs her feet with a hard brush. Mother hands Chiyo her dark tabi (socks) and geta (rough wood sandals.)  13
Inside, you wear these. Outside, these. We don’t display our naked feet like monkeys. Next, Mother impatiently wraps Chiyo in a servant‘’s kimo

Remember to always shut the shed door, so the rats don’t get in. If I ever find it open--even an inch-- it’s the bamboo stick for you. Now get to work. Be quiet! Hatsumomo is sleeping. (calling) Pumpkin!
Chiyo scrubs the stepping stones while Pumpkin cleans the shed. Pumpkin explains in a whisper (which gets louder as she continues):

Two nights ago Hatsumomo had to stay at the tea-house until dawn, entertaining three Judges--and when she got home, she cried, “I‘m sooo tired!” And then she started-- (PUMPKIN makes a snoring sound) --and she knocked over a candle, and it singed her kimono and her futon started smoking, and Mother came in and said, “Pumpkin! You must stay awake, all night, so Hatsumomo doesn’t burn down the whole okiya!” (a breath, and then) When I am a geisha I will sleep as late as I want. I will wear a fancy kimono, and my hair will be in a split-peach!
A what? Pumpkin curls her tongue and sticks it out; it looks like “split peach.” Together, she and Chiyo giggle.  23 14

Why can’t you be QUIET? Pumpkin freezes in terror. Even with tousled hair and smudged mascara, Hatsumomo is gorgeous. She spies CHIYO instantly, and gives her a long, slow appraisal. , HATSUMOMO (cont'd) So this ‘is the’ new arrival? A pity she still stinks of fish. She lights a cigarette casually and moves toward Chiyo. Mother steps. out onto the veranda: HATSUMOMO (cont ‘d) Hope you didn’t pay much for her, Mother. Not with those eyes. Water runs away. Mother dumps her tobacco ashes into a bin:
I pay too much for all of you. Mother leaves. Smiling, Hatsumomo bends down and tucks ba Chiyo’s hair, a sisterly gesture.
Stay out of my room. Your fingers smell; I can’t have you touching my things. Her fingers linger.
Pumpkin and Chiyo carry water from the well in the garden
When can I go outside?
Outside the okiya? You can’t. It’s not allowed. Carrying their buckets INSIDE, the girls climb the narrow fixed ladder that leads to the roof. Pumpkin climbs ahead
How will I find Satsu?  15

You can’t just walk up to every house in the Hanamachi. Do you know how many there are? CHIYO shakes her head “no.” YOUNG PUMPKIN (cont'd) ‘ Look. Pumpkin arrives on the roof and looks out over the Hanama [we don’t see yet]. Chiyo pulls herself up, sees with a j

Against a backdrop of softly rounded misty hills are THOUSANDS UPON THOUSANDS OF SLATE-BLUE TILED ROOFS so impenetrably close together, they seem almost to overlap. Pumpkin dumps her bucket into the water tank, splashing s on the tiles. Chiyo, crushed, stares at the maze of roofs INT. GRANNY’S ROOM - OKIYA. DAY. [WINTER]. 24 Chiyo carries a tray laden with food for Granny: rice and tiny white fishlings with dead, black eyes. She places it down in front of the old woman, who barks:

It is freezing! Close the window. Dutifully, Chiyo goes to the window and starts to pull it shut. Outside--on the street--she can’t help noticing: Hatsumomo, with a handsome young man; KOICHI (30s). With smile, he pulls her into a clandestine embrace. He kisses her neck, and whispers in her ear. Hatsumomo dissolves in girlish giggles. For a moment, Chiyo is absorbed by the sight of them. She snaps back to attention when she hears:

Chiyo! Chiyo yanks the window shut tightly. MOTHER (cont'd) Chiyo! Come quickly!  16 2 25 INT. HATSUMOMO‘S ROOM. DAY. [WINTER]. 25 Mother, cradling her ugly Japanese spaniel TAKU, slides o Hatsumomo’s door, revealing a room in disarray.
Hatsumomo is at the bath house. Tidy up.' '
But she made me promise--

Hatsumomo does not run this okiya. She gives Chiyo a sharp poke and Chiyo forces herself to into the room. Futon and quilts are piled in a tangled heap. Grimy white tabis and old wooden sushi boxes lie strewn among crumple tissues and spilled face powder and movie-photo magazines Chiyo leans down to pick up a box of powder; she does not hear Hatsumomo come in:

Why, look who's in my room. Chiyo jumps up. Hatsumomo snatches up her dusting powder: HATSUMOMO (cont ’d) Did you touch this?? (sniffs, sarcastic) I can just hear the General now. “Why, Hatsumomo. You used to smell of jasmine; what’s this new perfume?” (wrinking her nose in distaste) “Blowfish?” (savagely) I told you never to touch my things! Can't you understand why?
Because your General will say, “Hatsumomo, you stink.” Hatsumomo stares at her, displeased with her delivery.
> At least you don’t smell as bad as your sister. (MORE)
26 17 HATSUMOMO (cont'd) You know she was here. She came by, looking for you.
(stunned) What?
(ingenuous) ‘ Was I wrong to ask her to leave?
(with poignant urgency) Please. Tell me where she is. Hatsumomo looks at her with a luminous smile.
Only if you swear yourself to me first. Yes? Now get out.

The only reason Mother tolerates Hatsumomo is because she brings in good money. Auntie kneels amid a feast of colors, folding the many si kimono piled around her, then placing them neatly in lacquered boxes. Chiyo climbs a ladder and places the box in stacks along the walls. AUNTIE (cont’d) Never forget, it is Hatsumomo who pays for your supper. The clothes on your back. By the time she was twenty, she had already earned back her purchase price. Unheard of! She has. been the talk of the hanamachi ever since. Chiyo curious fingers one of the kimono:
These are all hers? Auntie snatches the kimono away.
Certainly not. They belong to the okiya. (displays summer kimono) (MORE)

27 28 18 AUNTIE (cont'd) A kimono like this, made of Tatsumura silk? It would take a lifetime to earn! A Sea Captain had this made for Granny when she was only fourteen. Under Auntie’s deft folding, the exquisite embroidery disappears and the kimono goes into a red lacquered box: ‘AUNTIE (cont'd) A geisha needs an elegant wardrobe, just like an artist needs ink! If she is not properly dressed, then she is not a true geisha.
Nobody told me what a geisha is.

You will find out soon enough. I have news for you, child. Chiyo looks at her, puzzled. AUNTIE (cont‘’d) ...Mother has determined. It is off to school with you. (beat) You are to become geisha. cur TO:

Pumpkin’s feet hurry down the STEP-TANSU, Chiyo behind he The girls wear simple cotton school kimono. At the entrance of the okiya, Pumpkin hops into her shoes Mother unfastens the bolt on the gate and hurries Pumpkin Chiyo through:
Quick. Quick. For the first time since her arrival, Chiyo steps into th street. Pumpkin yanks her --

location: STREETS OF THE HANAMACHI. VARIOUS. EARLY MORNING. 28

text: Pumpkin and Chiyo run down the street, wooden geta clatte on the paving stones.  19

The girls race across a bridge that spans the flowing Sonogawa, gracefully overhung with bare-limbed cherry tre Chiyo’s head swivels at TWO MAIKO walking past, their hai fashioned in the traditional split-peach style. Pumpkin grins, and points at them. Once again, she curls her tong into a “split peach.” Together she and Chiyo laugh. Pumpkin pulls Chiyo after h into a tunnel --
Hurry! As they run, Pumpkin jumps up to touch a low-hanging FISH CARVING and make it swing; a child‘s ritual. She races do a jumbled alley toward the theatre. Suddenly, Chiyo break rank:
{with resolve) Pumpkin! I’m sorry; I‘m going to run-- I’m going to find Satsu-- This makes PUMPKIN stop, cold.
No! Chiyo, don't! (beat) You will ruin your own chances, and mine too! Please. Stay with me! Pumpkin notices a morsel of food in the gutter. She gives cry of discovery in Japanese.
Mite, mite! To Chiyo's disbelief, Pumpkin squats down and snatches up dirty skewer of food fallen from a vendor's cart. She tak a bite: PUMPKIN (cont'd) Mm, squid! Pumpkin pulls Chiyo into --  29 30

The girls race along walkways to the school’s entrance, Pumpkin still chewing the squid -- ‘ YOUNG PUMPKIN (CONT’D) If you are not careful, Mother will toss you back onto the street, and then what? You will wind up with your obi tied in front.
“In front?”
You know. A prostitute. Because they spend so much time on their backs.

What is a “prostitute”? * Pumpkin doesn’t reply but climbs a wall of cubby holes li ladder and puts her sandals at the top. Chiyo follows. Pumpkin jumps down and grabs a shingle from the basket by entry and hangs it on the wall among HUNDREDS OF NAMES. Chiyoe tries to read them, but Pumpkin pulls her away:
Look for your sister later!

As Chiyo and Pumpkin race to class. They run by a row of 6 MAIKO, who go through precise danc movements as the FEMALE TEACHER (elegant, older) beats ti with her folded fan, calling out the steps in Japanese. A silver-haired GEISHA beats a tsuzumi. Pumpkin and Chiyo cut through the school garden past a TE CEREMONY CLASS (5 Geisha) and a CALLIGRAPHY CLASS (6 Maik led by one female teacher.). They pass a tatami room where 5 GEISHA play the shamisen by a MALE TEACHER, and enter: A classroom where a ragged line of 8 YOUNG GIRLS in cotto kimono try to follow a weary FEMALE TEACHER. A STUDENT kneels by a small Victorela, winding the scratchy recordi  31

The Teacher barks out the steps in Japanese, hitting the girls with her fan. Pumpkin and Chiyo dart into line at the back of the room, the Teacher bears down upon them, smacking her fan as she shouts out the time in cadence:
You - are - late! The Teacher whacks Pumpkin with her fan, keeping time, as Pumpkin tries clumsily to perform the steps and Chiyo tri to follow. The Teacher shoves the shoji door closed.

location: ENTRY AREA OF OKIYA. LATE NIGHT.

text: Alone, Chiyo kneels, trying to stay awake as she practice her shamisen. The sound of raucous LAUGHTER:

Sssh, Hatsumomo-san, you’1ll wake the entire house. Hatsumomo and her geisha friend KORIN (20s) arrive drunk giggling. Korin spies Chiyo: KORIN (cont‘d) Your big sister is thirsty. So am I. Go get us some beer.
I’m not in the mood for beer.
I know what you're in the mood for, and his name is Koichi. Hatsumomo flares; she doesn't want Korin to give away her secret:
What did you say? *
I'm sorry. I forgot -- *
You’re just jealous someone cares for me!  22
Hatsumomo opens a package wrapped in silk. She spreads ou ivory colored, embroidered kimono.
Guess who this belongs to? ‘ ' Hatsumomo wets an ink block: HATSUMOMO (cont'd) I will give you a clue. A geisha as desired as she is...ought to keep a close eye on her clothes!
It‘s Mameha’s?? How did you get it?
Bribed her maid. She laughs, enjoying her own cleverness. Hatsumomo dips a calligraphy brush, and gives it to Korin. Korin begins giggling; she has a failure of nerve:

Oh I can’t. I can’t. (eyeing Chiyo) Give it to her. She thrusts the brush back at Hatsumomo. Hatsmomo smiles Chiyeo, who shrinks back. Hatsumomo grabs Chiyo's wrist a forces the brush into her hand, points to a place on the kimono --

There. Chiyo hesitates. Their eyes lock: HATSUMOMO (cont'd) Remember? You swore yourself to me. Chiyo reluctantly takes up the brush. HATSUMOMO (cont‘d) Now then, little Chiyo. It’s time to practice your calligraphy.  33 34 35 23 Hatsumomo points to a place on the kimono. Chiyo touches brush to the milky fabric, leaving a smear of heavy black ink. Korin giggles. Hatsumomo glares at Chiyo as if to sa “Again.” Chiyo wets her brush a second time. EXT. MAMEHA‘S APARTMENT BUILDING NEAR THE SONOGAWA. NIGHT
Hatsumomo and Korin huddle with Chiyo in the shadows:

Do not let anybody see you. Chiyo walks quickly and leaves the folded kimono at the d A figure opens the door, flooding Chiyo’s face with light Chiyo sees a beautiful woman--MAMEHA (29)--whose long lon glossy hair flows over a nearly transparent kimono. Their eyes meet. Chiyo runs blindly --
Gripping Chiyo, Mother pours a bucket of water over her b and begins severely lashing her with a bamboo rod.
Thieving rat! That kimono was worth more than you!
Careful, Okasan! You will hurt yourself more than her. Let me. Auntie seizes the rod and Mother walks back into the Okiy

Kneel. Chiyo kneels, weeping, ashamed. Auntie painfully lowers h twisted hip and sits on the stone step. AUNTIE (cont'd) What have you done to Hatsumomo? Chiyo looks up tearfully.  36 37 24 ’ CHIYO I haven't done anything, I promise you. :

Whatever you've done to anger her, you'd be wise to stop. Now. . (when Chiyo is silent) You would like 'Hatsumomo to be your big sister, wouldn’t you? Then you must learn to please her. (beat) Lie face down. Chiyo obeys. Auntie gets to her feet painfully, favoring hip. AUNTIE (cont'd) When I was young, Granny was Mother of this okiya. One day I was naughty, speaking out of turn, as you often do. Granny whipped me so fiercely, I was crippled. And so I never becamé a geisha. I could never repay my debt. Auntie’s rod comes down, swish! AUNTIE (cont'd) And so everyone in the okiya suffered. Another swish! Chiyo suffers the beating stoically. AUNTIE (cont'd) (when Chiyo complies) I will beat you “just so.” To spare you the agony I have endured. Swish!
Mother listens with satisfaction, then turns up the radio
Auntie walks away, leaving Chiyo sobbing on the ground. Chiyo hears the veranda shoji open. Hatsumomo lounges against her door with a sly smile. She is drinking sake.  38 39 25
I told you not to let anybody see you. , Chiyo turns on her with tears of pain:
I have kept my promise. So tell me. Where is she? Hatsumomo licks the rim of sake cup, then puts it down. S reaches out to Chiyo, cradling the child’s hands in her o
She's in the next hanamachi in a house called Tatsuyo. (beat) Trust me, little Chiyo. You will find her. cur TO:

RAIN sheets from tile roofs. WATER rushes along the stree as in a stream, overflowing the curbstones. INT. HATSUMOMO’S ROOM. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. 39 Hatsumomo stands in her wig cap, looking wan except for vibrant red lips. A cigarette dangles from her mouth. Mr. BEKKU forcefully tugs back her obi ties. Hatsumomo bridle and hisses:

Tighter! And BEKKU gives another fierce yank. The sound of Hatsumomo’s sharp little cry stops Chiyo, who peeks throu the doorway. Hatsumomo catches Chiyo’s face in the mirror HATSUMOMO (cont'd) Chiyo! You will walk me to the Yukimoto teahouse, won't you? They lock eyes; a private communique sizzles between them HATSUMOMO (cont‘d) Then you will stand and wait for me?  41 42 43 44 45 46 26 EXT. HANAMACHI STREETS. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. They set out, Chiyo, shivering, holding a scarlet oiled-p umbrella high over Hatsumomo as she lifts her kimono abov the puddles. EXT: YUKIMOTO TEAHOUSE COURTYARD. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. Rain batters down. Chiyo, soaked to the bone, waits under scant shelter of the red umbrella. EXT: YUKIMOTO TEAHOUSE COURTYARD. NIGHT. RAIN. {WINTER]. The tea room’s front doors are open slightly to the courtyard. Through a decorative screen, we glimpse for th first time the hidden teahouse world:

A simple room with handsome golden screens and warm, bric red walls, polished dark wood. Hatsumomo and TWO OTHER GEISHA kneel before a GROUP OF MEN seated at low portable tables, pouring sake. Laughing and smiling, Hatsumomo loo the part of a perfect geisha, the very soul of beauty and wit. EXT, YUKIMOTO TEAHOUSE COURTYARD. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. The red umbrella sits open on the ground in the front courtyard garden, abandoned. Rain pours in torrents. EXT. PATH ALONG THE RIVER. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. CLOSE ON CHIYO’S FEET RUNNING as her wooden sandals pound sure-footedly along the river path, splashing through puddles. EXT: NIGHT STREETS IN THE NEXT HANAMACHI. NIGHT. RAIN. {WINTER]. Chiyo runs past DRUNKEN MEN into seedier streets: EXT: THE SEEDY PART OF TOWN. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. The rundown “teahouses” in this hanamachi look different the elegant Yukimoto. 40 42 43 44 45 46  a7 27 Here, the roof tiles are crooked and broken. Under cracke lanterns, WOMEN huddle in doorways and sit lined up behin barred windows, their white faces and red lips crudely painted. . Chiyo speaks to a WOMAN in a doorway. The Woman points, gives Chiyo directions. Chiyo hurries on.
Chiyo yanks on a wooden door, knocking as hard as she can Finally a small panel slides open. An OLD CRONE looks out

Satsu. The panel snaps shut. Chiyo beats on the door, to no avai CHIYO (cont'd) Satsu! From Yoroido! Satsu! Chiyo stands uncertainly, soaked to the skin, her hair an thin kimono plastered to her body. She casts around helplessly, and sees: From a dark side doorway, a MAN in Western clothes depart Behind him in the shadows, Chiyo can see a young woman; h silhoutte is familiar. Chiyo calls: CHIYO (cont‘d) Satsu? Satsu! Satsu edges into the lantern’s crimson glow and Chiyo rac to her.
Chiyo-chan! They embrace but something is in the way. Chiyo realizes: Satsu’s cumbersome obi is tied in front. SATSU (cont'd) What took you so long--
--But Satsu, I tried--
(recriminatory) I went to your okiya weeks ago! They laughed, and turned me away---
Chiyo sees in the light: Satsu’s face is marred by a beat
-Please, I did not know--
I thought you'd forgotten me--
Satsu, no--I could never--
I've missed you so much--
Let's leave--tonight--
But we’ll need money, Chiyo--I know where I can steal some, first thing tomorrow--

They don’t acknowledge one another; their eyes are fixed on the stage. Meanwhile, Pumpkin grins coyly at her friend Chiyo, and c her tongue in a “split peach”, just as she did when they children. Chiyo suppresses a smile, and executes a gracef turn without missing a beat. Pumpkin, however, is fatally amused by her own hijinks; she’s thrown off balance and d her fan. Mameha casts a discreet, competitive look in Hatsumomo’s direction, to gauge her response. Hatsumomo sits with her back stiff, and shoots Pumpkin a look that could straight bonsai tree-- CLOSE UP: --as a coal stick glides across an arched eyebr accentuating it with black---
---Chiyo’s long, black hair is combed out flat by A MALE HAIRDRESSER (middle-aged), who then applies hot wax with iron.

Beauty is cruelty.  87 88 89 90 91 55 Chiyo grimaces in protest-- INT. CHIYO’S ROOM. NIGHT. [WINTER] ~ DAY --as Mother replaces her pillow with a wooden stand. Next Mother sprinkles rice powder liberally around the base. I her new split-peach hairstyle, Chiyo rests her neck on th stand; she ‘tries itto make herself comfortable, closing eyes-- INT. CHIYO’S ROOM. MORNING. [WINTER] --which open the next morning. Slowly Chiyo realizes her head has slid off the wooden stand. Rice powder is matted her hair and eyelashes. She tries in vain to pluck it out Hatsumomo stands in the doorway, laughing--

text: --as Hatsumomo and Pumpkin exit, Pumpkin’s coiffure immaculately lacquered, every strand in perfect place. Meanwhile--inside--Mameha shakes her head, sympatheticall the Hairdresser once again draws wax through poor Chiyo's hair-- CLOSE UP: --as a bejeweled ornament slides gracefully int the upswept hair-style of a maiko-- INT. MAMEHA’S APARTMENT. DAY. [WINTER] --colorful maiko kimono festoon the room. Chiyo goes “shopping” among Mameha’s collection. Mameha holds up a beautiful kimono-- CLOSE UP: --and two pale arms slide into a sheer under- kimono--
--now dressed in fluttering kimono, Chiyo and Mameha step into the street.
The fortune-teller suggested November 3rd for your debut-- 87 88 89 90 91  92 56
(crestfallen) November? Can't it be sooner?

Sooner? (laughing) Water certainly likes to rush! CLOSE UP: --in quick succession, eight silk bands called are drawn and bound-- MAMEHA (cont'd) You cannot call yourself a true geisha until you can stop a man in his tracks, with a single look. CLOSE UP: --a lavishly embroidered cream kimono closes, l over right--
No one can do that. Mameha turns her back to the street:

Choose someone for me. Chiyo indicates a PASSING MAN who walks absently toward t Mameha takes a few small steps, her eyes downcast. As the Man reaches her, Mameha lifts her eyes to meet his. The M stops, he turns to watch Mameha go. Chiyo, amazed, hurries to catch up with Mameha.
If I can do that - may I debut sooner? CLOSE UP: A man’s hand yanks the obi strings tight on the back of a geisha’s kimono.
Perhaps.
(game now) Go ahead, then. Choose someone for me, Onei-san.  93
Mameha looks around, selects a DELIVERY BOY pedalling in street, his bicycle loaded with a towering stack of bundl

Make him fall over. With one look. Close up: --eyes flash in a hand mirror-- Chiyo hesitates anxiously. Then she sees a solution: A TRUCK is backing slowly out of an alley. In a split-second, Chiyo boldly steps into the street and stares directly into the Delivery Boy’s face as he passes Surprised, the Boy momentarily turns his head -- -- then hears a truck’s HORN. The Boy brakes and swerves The bicycle’s heavy load topples, spilling its driver and cargo across the pavement, Mameha sends Chiyo a wry look. CLOSE UP: ---a tin make-up box slams shut-- MAMEHA (cont ‘d) You are ready.

MOTHER and AUNTIE, dressed for the occasion, wait impatie in the entry-way. Mameha flings open the shoji screen of tatami room to reveal: Chiyo, now as flawless and painted as a gorgeous, Japanes doll, in the full make-up of a maiko. Her hair is waxed a shiny black; Mameha’s richly embroidered “butterfly-sleev kimono falls in lush pools of silk at her feet. Chiyo mov across the room and stops at a full length mirror. She stares at herself in the glass. Tears well in her eyes. *
Chiyo looks to Mameha. Even Bekku’s impressed. *  94 95
Mother intercedes-— *
Hurry up! You are not making money standing there gawking at yourself--

CLOSE on Chiyo’s foot as the snowy tabi parts and the tho of her shoe slides between. the gloved toes. Chiyo walks down the path on her tall maiko shoes and pau under the lantern, in the same spot where she first laid on Hatsumomo. Behind her Auntie strikes the flint.
For luck. SPARKS fly behind Chiyo.
In the garden, Mameha and Chiyo exchange three cups of sa (served by the teahouse-owner) in a “sisters” ritual. Mot and Auntie stand in attendance.

This binds us together forever as sisters. Today you leave your childhood and cast away your name. From this day forward, you will be known by a new one...with the same lilt, the same music as the water you resemble... (a pause, and then) .--"Sayuri.” Sayuri, formerly Chiyo, bows her head in gratitude.  96

The TEAHOUSE OWNER--teetering with a tray stacked with sa and beer--barrels down the deep red hallway toward the te room. LAUGHTER and conversation spill from the room as sh flings open the shoji doors. EIGHT MEN are seatled in conversational groups at low tab around three sides of the room. In the seat of honor, we recognize The Baron. The OTHER MEN are mostly older and a wealthy, their spirits loosened by sake. The host, Hatsumomo's favorite client THE GENERAL (55, chainsmoker) wears a Japanese military uniform. TWO GEISHA move gracefully among the tables, serving sake they chat among the men. Behind a screen, before they make their entrance:
Tonight, you will attend the Baron. CHIYO looks at her, uncertain. Isn‘t he Mameha‘s territor MAMEHA (cont'd) A new maiko always attends the honored guest. Ready?
Onei-san, thank you. Mameha smiles. They enter,, bowing on the floor, murmuring their greetin etc. ‘Then they hurry toward the Baron with small steps. General lifts his sake cup:

Friends, we have the pleasure to witness the debut of a new maiko. Some of the men applaud, and all lift their glasses. With guick small steps that make her kimono hem ripple, Sayuri approaches The Baron and kneels, blushing. The Baron eyes her playfully, admiring. To Mameha:
I remember those eyes. What was her name? Mameha looks to Sayuri, giving her permission to respond. Sayuri feels a pang of pleasure as she speaks the word:  97 60
“Sayuri”.

(whisper) You may replenish the Baron’s tea. Sayuri self-consciously takes up the teapot. She aims the spout low, close to the Baron’s cup, so the aroma doesn’t escape. Meanwhile-- with the other hand--she draws back h kimono sleeve, exposing her wrist, pausing exactly as Mam has taught her. The Baron’s eyes drift to Sayuri’s arm. After a few secon have elapsed, Sayuri is mortified to realize that the Bar cup is still empty -- no tea is pouring from the spout of depleted tea pot.
She’s determined, isn’t she? If there’d been a drop of tea in that pot, I believe Sayuri would have gotten it out-- Everyone laughs. Under her make-up, Sayuri is flushed wit embarrassment.
Now don’t tease, Baron. It's her very first time.

Mameha’‘s fingers pluck the strings of her shamisen, accompanying Sayuri. Sayuri gracefully dances with two fans, just as Mameha ta her. As Sayuri dramatically tosses and catches one of the fans, she sees: The Teahouse Owner leading in Hatsumomo and Pumpkin. Hatsumomo seductively advances on the Baron’s table, Pump in tow.

Baron...Forgive me for intruding - General Tottori was good enough to ask us to call. The General, tipsy, has no memory of it but he is pleased fill her cup with sake. Sayuri and Mameha end the dance, the men applaud.  61 HATSUMOMO (cont ‘d) What a beautiful dance! Yes, Pumpkin? Deftly, Hatsumomo takes a fan from Pumpkin and demonstrat HATSUMOMO (cont ‘d) Her fans are so hypnotic that you never ndtice her feet. (turns to Sayuri) What is your name?
Her name is Sayuri.

“Sayuri” - a name as sweet as she is! (to the General) I‘m afraid these days, even a common chambermaid can call herself a geisha. {her eyes narrowing in Sayuri's direction) So it's nice to see such a sincere young maiko. Isn’t it?
(caught in the middle, stammering) Why, yes. Indeed.
(to Sayuri) Surely you would like to thank Hatsumomo for her gracious compliments.
There is so much I would like to say to Hatsumomo.
Sometimes, the wisest remark is to say nothing.
What better advice to follow than your own?
Sayuri--
98 62 Sayuri bows low to Hatsumomo.
I was a maiko myself once.
Of course. But it’s been such a very long, long, long, long... The Baron and the men laugh. Sayuri continues demurely: SAYURI (cont‘d) ---time. Hatsumomo bridles.
Little Sayuri has studied to be a geisha for such a short time, she hasn‘t learned her manners. (to the General) Tell me. Would you ever send a man into battle before he's ready?
Never. My men are trained to kill.
(to Mameha) Perhaps her debut came too soon.

{stifling laughter) On the contrary, Hatsumomo....I'd say...I'd say she hit her target!... The Baron laughs, too, and the laughter grows, filling th room. Hastumomo glares, ashen. Pumpkin bites her lip to k from grinning. Mameha smiles at how her protege has handl herself. Sayuri bears the peaceful look of triumph. cur TO: INT: SAYURI‘S ROOM. THE OKIYA. NIGHT/DAWN. [WINTER] 98 Abrupt awakening: Hatsumomo jerks Sayuri awake by the hai and slaps her. In a quiet rage, she whispers:
I shall destroy you.  99 100 63 With another vicious yank, Hatsumomo leaves her.
Shaded by a colorful parasol, Mameha and Sayuri ride in A RICKSHAW past an ornate pagoda; Sayuri in full maiko atti and make-up.

She can destroy you. She will spread rumors, stalk you from tea- house to tea-house, then steal your clients and turn them over to Pumpkin! All in the hope that Mrs. Nitta adopts Pumpkin instead of you!
What can we do?

We've got to out-wit her. To find a safe haven...somewhere beyond her reach, where you can practice your skills without any interference. And I’ve found just the place. (gives her a card) Your first sumo match.
What?

(nodding) It is sold out. Hatsumomo could not gain admission if she were a rat and scurried under the seats. SAYURI smiles, her appetite whetted. MAMEHA (cont'd) Today you will meet Iwamura Ken. He founded the Iwamura Electric Company in Osaka. (MORE)
MAMEHA (cont'd) My client for years. His partner Nobu...well, they say what he lacks in charm, he makes up for in savvy--
You don't approve of Nobu?
He does npt approve of us. * Off Sayuri’s dismayed look: MAMEHA (cont'd) You like a challenge, don't you? Mameha laughs merrily, as the RICKSHAW passes over a grac bridge in the Japanese countryside.

Suspended over the mounded dohyo (clay sumo ring) is a ro resembling a,Shinto shrine, and hung at the corners with giant colored tassels honoring the four season. All aroun the ring rise tiers of boxes filled with kneeling SPECTAT In the ring, two almost naked rikishi (FIRST PAIR OF SUMO WRESTLERS) are already in combat as Mameha and Sayuri mak their way to the first tier boxes .~ As Sayuri and Mameha approach the box where their clients wait, MEN turn their heads, looking to see which box will receive the honor of two such beautiful geishas.

(whispers) Be attentive. i will do the rest. Sayuri follows Mameha nervously toward two men seated ina first tier box. Sayuri realizes that one of the two men seems somehow familiar. He rises and greets Mameha warmly It is The Chairman. Sayuri’s heart is pounding as she bow MAMEHA (cont'd) Chairman Iwamura, President Nobu, * this is my new younger sister Sayuri.
Hajimemashite.
As Sayuri gazes momentously into the face she has longed see, the Chairman abruptly averts his eyes, and speaks instead to NOBU:

Nobu-san. NOBU (42, strong presence of power and intelligence) ‘is focused on the match. He cries out the name of the wrestl whom he sponsors ("Tochinoyama!”), then berates him in Japanese. The Chairman tries again: CHAIRMAN (cont’d) Nobul When Nobu turns to greet Sayuri, she feels a slight shock Nobu's face is disfigured, badly scarred on one side; his right hand is a web of puckered scars. Mameha deftly make the introduction --

Nobu Toshikazu-san. Nobu gives a shout as THE SECOND SET OF WRESTLERS mount t ring. Mameha seats Sayuri between the Chairman and Nobu, manages to whisper in Sayuri’s ear: MAMEHA (cont'd) Injured in Manchuria. War hero.

Sayuri, is this your first encounter with sumo? Sayuri nods, too nervous to speak. She is aware of how cl they sit, her leg and his almost touching as they kneel. CHAIRMAN (cont’d)} Nobu-san will have to educate you. I cannot tell one wrestler from the next.
CHAIRMAN (cont'd) (gestures around tent) Did you notice our contribution? Mameha notices the electric lights, gives a delighted cry
Lovely! The CHAIRMAN turns to Sayuri:
We closed a new deal in the countryside. We're harnessing the power of water to bring electricity to some of the smaller villages.
It was in the newspaper, wasn't it?

With the Chairman's picture, yes? (teasing his friend) You compensate for all my shortcomings, don't you? A RUNNER delivers a pot of tea and cups. Sayuri takes up pot to pour the Chairman his tea. She draws back her slee and breaks the silence:
May I ask: How does someone harness the power of water? The Chairman glances at Sayuri's wrist, then meets her ga evenly--
You should never ask an engineer to explain a thing. Because he will--
Iwamura. Let the girl watch sumo! Sayuri, teapot in mid-air, freezes, her gaze riveted: Acr the ring, Hatsumomo is arriving with Korin.

Korin, that little jade! She has brought a guest. They see: Hatsumomo looks through opera glasses at the Chairman. Mameha raises her fan for a private tete-a-tete with Sayuri: MAMEHA (cont ‘d) Quick, Turn your attention to Nobu--
(with dread) But Mameha-neisan--

(rapid-fire) She finds him repulsive. She’d never steal him away. Mislead her. Mameha lowers her fan. Instantly Sayuri shifts the teapot Nobu's cup. The Chairman's face falls, but he works to conceal his disappointment. Sayuri improvises:
Perhaps Nobu-san will be kind enough to explain the rules of the match. The Chairman glances into his cup; it’s only half full. Mameha swoops in, pouring the rest of his tea.

Three things matter in life: Sumo, business and war. Understand one, you know them all. But why should a geisha care? You spend your time plucking strings, and dancing. Nobu turns away, scowling; sips his tea. Sayuri senses Hatsumomo watching. She redoubles her efforts.
I humbly beg to differ. What is sumo but a dance between giants? What is business but a dance between companies? (beat) I‘d@ like to know about every kind of dance.
The Chairman smiles, impressed. Nobu begrudgingly begins pointing out elements of the match:

Shiomaki...They are throwing salt to purify the ring. The two combatants quickly move from their “fair play sta to a glowering crouth as they face off in the small ring. NOBU (cont ‘d) That man is Miyagiyama. The greatest fighter in Japan.
But he is so tiny--
Only compared to his opponent! Miyagiyama may use hataki komi--- are you listening? Sayuri has one eye on The Chairman, but quickly reforms:
Yes.

Hataki komi is a movement a smaller combatant uses to throw the larger man off balance. Victory does not always belong to the powerful-- Nobu watches intently as the Wrestlers prepare and throw salt, prepare again, building tension. He points brusquel NOBU (cont’d) Look. There. In his eyes. The Wrestlers tense and prepare to charge. At the same ti Mameha sees: Hatsumomo has left her seat and is making he way toward them. Mameha gathers herself apologetically:
I am afraid our time has come to a close--
Going sc soon?  102 69

Not yet--I want her to see-- The Wrestlers crouch on their fists. Finally the larger m SAIHO, charges. MILYAGIYAMA uses the force of Saiho'’s impact to swivel o the way. In that same instant, he brings his hand down on the back of Saiho's neck; Saiho flies over the lip of the ring and sprawls into the SPECTATORS. The encounter is ov in less than two seconds. NOBU (cont ‘d) Now that - is hataki komi.

I see now why you like Sumo. (with compassion for Nobu 's: deformities) You can never judge a man’s power by his appearance alone. Nobu looks at Sayuri--full on--for the first time. He’s truly touched by her insight. He says to Mameha:
You may bring her again.
Sayuri & Mameha leave the match, among a press of SPECTAT
What are we to do? Hatsumomo found us again!
Do not worry. Like a true sumo wrestler, you threw her off balance! Nobu is the perfect diversion. Sayuri peeks back at Chairman. Only Nobu watches them go.
(worried) Suppose he believes my advances...suppose he takes an interest in me?
And violates all his high-minded morals? Never.
But Oneisan...you heard him. He asked to see me again.

(musing) Yes....he did, didn’t he? (back to business) In the days ahead, Sayuri, I am going to require all your trust. I have it, don’t I? Sayuri nods. MAMEHA (cont'd) Good! Then our only enemy is time. 70 CcuT TO:
Sayuri digs through a stack of old newspapers near the st She tears one open and finds: A BLACK & WHITE PHOTOGRAPH the Chairman. INT.

Alone, Sayuri uses a hair ornament to pry out the false bottom of a lacquered box. In the compartment, she places the news photo of the Chairman next to the same handkerch he gave her so many years ago. cuT TO: EXT. NEAR MAMEHA’S APT. DAY. [SPRING] Sayuri hastens over the Sonogawa footbridge. from her balcony. Mameha watches 103 104 105  106
INT. MAMEHA‘S APARTMENT. DAY. [SPRING] 106 Mameha uses the tiny blade of a folding knife to open the seam of a beautiful maiko kimono. The MAID ushers Sayuri in, then leaves.
Onei-san.
Tonight, we will deliver a quick blow to Hatsumomo. Hataki komi.
How? Mameha drapes the kimono on Sayuri and checks the split s against Sayuri’s right leg.
We will meet Nobu-san at the Tsunashima restaraunt. But * first....a visit to Dr. Crab! Mameha ‘pinches the end of a smouldering charcoal pencil
Dr. Crab? Mameha pulls up Sayuri’s kimono exposing her leg. SAYURI (cont'd) Onei-san!

Hold still. It’s a little nickname he has earned over the years. Mameha pokes her eyebrow charcoal into the slit to mark Sayuri’s leg. Sayuri looks on bewildered. MAMEHA (cont'd) Now cut your leg where I've marked it.
(shocked) What?
Or I will cut it for you.  107 72
Onei-san...have you gone mad?
(suddenly, harshly) Do you trust me, or don’t you? Well? Mameha’s dead seridus. Sayuri picks up the knife, her fac study in perplexion.
Couldn't I just pretend to have a stomach ache?

Go ahead! Do it! Sayuri swallows hard, then presses the blade against the charcoal mark on her thigh. She gives a gasp of pain. Mam says, almost with a lilt: . MAMEHA (cont ‘d) And now we go fishing for a certain Crab... INT. DR. CRAB’S CLINIC & HOME. HANAMACHI. DAY. [SPRING] 1 DR. CRAB (45, odd, meticulous) wears a metal head reflect

Careless with the sewing scissors, were you? Mortified, Sayuri lies on the examining table under a gha clinical light. She wears the kimono Mameha prepared for her, opened to expose her pale thigh. DR. CRAB (cont‘d) Right through your beautiful kimono...Pity. He inserts his forefinger through the slit and wiggles it his finger grazing Sayuri’s skin.
It won’t leave a scar, will it? Sayuri is a special girl at a very special time in her life. Dr. Crab instantly understands the allusion, of course.  108 109

With those eyes, you must be quite a commodity. He examines the cut, bringing his face close to her leg. DR. CRAB (cont’d) A clean cut. Won’t leave a mark, I promise. But I‘d best prescribe a bit of antiseptic-- He smiles down at Sayuri as his fingers massage some salv a circular fashion all around the tiny red wound.

Open-air verandas adjoin, decorated with glowing lanterns On the lower veranda, Hatsumomo attends the General and h MILITARY CRONIES. She displays Pumpkin to them like a chi doll. The CAMERA moves on & we see: On the next veranda, Nobu, Chairman and BUSINESSMEN chat amongst themselves. Wrapped in fur-trimmed cloaks over their kimono, Mameha a Sayuri prepare to enter. Mameha shows Sayuri a tiny origa box that opens--like a blooming flower--to reveal a SWEET RICE CAKE with a dab of red.

Ekubo. At the right moment, slip it to Nobu. Discreetly.. (at her puzzled look) He will know what it means. The MAIDS bring in trays. Sayuri and Mameha follow them i kimono hems ruffling in a liquid flow.

For a fleeting moment, Sayuri and the Chairman lock eyes; skirts past him. The Chairman smiles as Mameha bows: MAMEHA (cont'd) Konbanwa. At the General's table, Hatsumomo watches, amused, as Say obediently hurries to Nobu’s side. Nobu extends his sake to Sayuri impatiently. . Il ‘
You have kept us waiting.

Please forgive us, Nobu-san. With an apologetic smile, Sayuri quickly takes up his bot Sayuri sees: Hatsumomo, spilling gossip into the General’ ear. In response, the General glances over at Nobu and laughs. Then he whispers the gossip to the person next to him. Soon, the scuttlebutt is circling the table. Sayuri realizes--with a jolt--that Nobu is speaking to he
The Chairman thinks I should take more pleasure in life...music, and the theater! What is your impression? The Chairman looks to Sayuri, curious to hear her answer.
It is useless to push a cart sideways. The Businessmen laugh. Sayuri blushes, amends: SAYURI (cont'd) One could not wish Nobu-san to be anyone but Nobu-san.
I could not agree more. He extends his cup to Nobu warmly. CHAIRMAN (cont‘d) I owe this man everything. Kampai.
Kampai.  2
The men drink.
--He gives me too much credit, as usual--

The Chairman smiles at Nobu’s modesty. A maid brings in a tray of fresh sake, and places it on t table. Nobu produces a small box wrapped in silk. He unwraps it, and hands it to Sayuri. t NOBU (cont’d) (downplaying the gift) It’s a trinket. I found it a few days ago. An awkward silence. Sayuri, The Chairman and Mameha are a speechless. Finally:
Why, Nobu. I had no idea you were so sentimental.
Call it my new leaf. The Chairman is quietly stunned. Sayuri glances at Mameha, uncertain how to respond. Mameh gives a signal nod: Thank him. Sayuri bows, blushing:
Arigato gozaimasu.
My mother...she used to wear something similar. Nobu lifts the lid of the box: A simple but elegant COMB. Sayuri just stares at it. NOBU (cont'd) You do not like it?  110
Forgive me, I have never received a present before. A most unwelcome Hatsumomo appears, Pumpkin at her heels, route to another affair:

Konbonwa. * (She notices Nobu‘s gift) * Ah, what a beautiful comb! * Kneeling, she takes the comb from the box and--with a surgeon’s precision--places the comb in Sayuri’s hair. HATSUMOMO (cont'd) Such a joyous moment, Sayuri! (with a glance at Nobu, * and then to Sayuri) * You are finally getting what you deserve. As Hatsumomo steps away, Sayuri lifts her gaze in time to catch the Chairman's guarded expression.
How lovely. Hatsumomo and Pumpkin bow before leaving:

And now will you excuse us, please? * We have another engagement. * (to Mameha) * Many, in fact. * (as they leave) * Pumpkin! * And--like a sudden tsunami--they vanish. Discreetly, Mame produces from her sleeve the origami box: The mizuage cak Bowing to Nobu, Sayuri covertly slips the box into his unscarred hand. Flustered, Nobu covers it with his scarre hand at once. Chairman intuits what has happened, looks away. Sayuri whispers:
You are most kind.
Mameha hurries along, Sayuri tries to keep up. She looks miserable, but Mameha is elated:  77
Now-- (hands her origami box) --give this one to Dr. Crab. Sayuri takes the box, but blurts:
Mameha, please’!
(surprised) You’re upset.
I want to trust you, I do! But you have to tell me what's going on--
(her voice rising in defense) I am ensuring your future--
But tell me how! TI beg you! | J They step up into a rickshaw. Mameha explains:
I am trying to orchestrate a bidding war.
What for?
Your most precious attribute.
And what is that?
Your mizuage. The rickshaw pulls away.
} Riding along in the rickshaw.

The rickshaw pulls away in the backround as Mameha leads Sayuri briskly down a covered walkway. MAMEHA (cont'd) When. you sjip the rice cake to Dr. Crab it is a sign that says your mizuage is ripe for sale. *
Mameha and Sayuri arrive at the entrance door. The TEA HO OWNER (female, 60, sophisticated) stops them:

fhe Doctor has no desire to see you tonight. - Or any night. Her sharp black eyes go to Sayuri accusingly and she shut the door. Mameha and Sayuri exchange a devastated look wh says: “Hatsumomo; who else?”
As Sayuri approaches, she hears Hatsumomo berating Pumpki

I spent the whole night sipping sake and beer--I need food, Pumpkin! Noodles! Something! Go out and fetch it now! Pumpkin stumbles down the steep tansu steps, harried. She draws up short at the sight of Sayuri and chokes back sob Sayuri touches her but she pushes past:
Pumpkin...Pumpkin...
I am not supposed to speak to you--  80
Hatsumomo can not treat you this way--
--she can treat me however she chooses-- Pumpkin groans inf frustration; her sandal thong has brok Sayuri quietly takes it from her to repair it:
Why can’t we speak, Pumpkin? You were my first friend in the world--
Our lives have changed now.
Hatsumomo went to see Dr. Crab, yes?
chiyo- chan, I have to go--
(more pointedly now) Didn't she?
I do not know-~-
Of course you know--you shadow her every step--
--if she did, would I tell you?--
--if you still care for me--
--you expect me to betray my big sister?--
--has she made you cruel, too--
(faltering) --no--  81
My Pumpkin always told the truth--
--but--
--the truth!--- Pumpkin fights her tears and finally breaks. She pulls Sayuri into the dirt corridor of the okiya:

Tonight...We went to the Tanizato to see Dr. Crab! I sat outside, but I could still hear through the screen. Hatsumomo-neisan said to him, “I live in the same okiya as Sayuri!” His eyes got big, and he said “Really? Tell me everything about her!” And she said, “Oh, sir, I mustn’t! It would only curl your toes!” That made him even More curious. “Well,” said Hatsumomo-neisan, as smooth as silk, “Did you know that she brings men back to her room?” “No!” he cried. “Common sailors, and fishermen, too,” said Hatsumomo- neisan. And the Doctor looked queasy, like he didn’t want to hear anymore. But she kept going. “At all hours, of the night, like an alleycat!.” And then the doctor got very quiet, and stared for the longest time at his hands. And Hatsumomo-neisan said, “What‘’s the matter? Have I told you more than you wanted to know?” Sayuri understands everything now. PUMPKIN (cont'd) I wanted to say something but how could I, Chiyo-chan, how? (then, still wincing) Am I really like her? Am I?
Of course not.
Is Mameha-san cruel to you, too?  114
No. She’s so kind to me, Pumpkin. But sometimes I worry she’s taking me further from the things I want. Sayuri helps her slip on the mended sandal.
That man, Nobu. (wrinkling her nose) Do you really like him?
(sadly) No.

That‘s what I thought. Do you like someone else? 82 Sayuri looks at Pumpkin; does she know? Sayuri blushes, a rises to leave: PUMPKIN (cont'd) Don’t worry about me, Chiyo-chan. I'll be fine. Better than fine. (beat) Mother plans to adopt me. ‘So my dream of having someplace to live out my life may come true. Jhah- ne! . Pumpkin hugs Sayuri then rushes out. Sayuri is stunned.
As they walk, Mameha and Sayuri talk in low tones:
We can still prevent it.
How? Hatsumomo has poisoned Dr. Crab against mel
Forget about him. There are plenty of other fish in the sea.
The Chairman has been kind-- “114  115 116
Sayuri! Nobu and the Chairman are business paxtners. They would never bid against one another. (beat) ‘ It is time we cast a wider net-- Mameha smiles, the wheels in her head turning.
Rain falls mistily along the narrow side-streets. Hatsumo darts homeward from the bathhouse.
Suppose you were the object of every man’s fantasy——
What do you mean?
--and became the most famous geisha in all Miyako--
But I am not.
You will be--~ Hatsumomo sees a festival poster on a kiosk and stares in disbelief: the PAINTING of a maiko with silver eyes can o be Sayuri. She tears it down with a “rip.”
At the table Sayuri, Pumpkin, Mother and Auntie eat their meal. Hatsumomo stalks in, the crumpled poster in her han
Who is responsible for this?
Ask Mameha. Fumpkin stares at the poster, aghast.  117 118 84
How did Sayuri get to be the lead?
(to Pumpkin) It’s your own fault! You should practice more! (to Hatsumomo ) You keep her otit too late, dragging her from teahouse to teahouse-- Hatsumomo looks at Sayuri, outraged.
(still forlorn) I want my picture made.
(to Sayuri, insinuating) What did Mameha do? Speak to the director “in private?”
Not every geisha uses that kind of currency.
I am looking forward to your performance. (with venom) You know how I adore watching you dance, Chiyo. She departs, with a flick of her finger upturning a dish sauce over the poster of Sayuri.

head_text.subj: INT/EXT. KABURENJO THEATRE AND COURTYARD LOBBY. NIGHT. 11

text: THEATRE-GOERS dressed in spring finery crowd the theatre entrance. RICKSHAWS pull up in front. An elaborately decorated one carries The GENERAL and HATSUMOMO. Blazing white lanterns bank A HUGE POSTER of Sayuri and her silve eyes. Out in public, the image is even more imposing.

From the wings we see 10 MAIKO on stage in identical cost ~ Pumpkin among them, nervous and trying hard -- twirling brilliantly colored fans.  a 119 85 Sayuri‘’s hands tremble as she tries in vain to slide a g ornament into her hair. Mameha glides into view in her mirror; she presses her cheek to Sayuri’s and whispers:
They‘ve all come...The Baron, Nobu- san, our beloved Hatsumomo and that dapper General of hers--
(a tad too fervently) Anybody else?
(arching an eyebrow) Even your old friend, Dr. Crab. Gently, Mameha takes the glass ornament from Sayuri’s ner fingers, and expertly places it in her coiffure.
Onei-san. What if I dance poorly- what if I disgrace myself, and no one takes interest--?
Shhhh. You will be glorious! Now it’s time.

A FIGURE appears at the back of the house, dressed as a courtesan in an ornate head-dress, in tall black lacquere shoes, carrying a translucent parasol -- Sayuri, making h entrance. “Snow” falls as she dances her way along the mirrored hanamichi (a long ramp that extends from the back of the house to the stage). When she spies the Chairman in the audience, she barely averts a stumble. CLOSE UPS reveal Mother, Auntie, Mr. Bekku, The General, Hatsumomo, Dr. Crab, The Baron, Mameha, and Nobu are watc from the audience. They are moved by Sayuri’s dance of unrequited love. The Chairman is particularly enthralled. As the dance comes to a close--and Sayuri descends into t madness of grief--she discards her parasol, steps out of shoes, loses her ornate cloak and soon falls weeping on t hanamichi. The snow swirls around her.
Taking care of.a little nuisance? ; a that .a naughty secret: cee a at BS The Baron, embarri BE ront of angered look. - Mameha, stung, covers.
122 123 124 89 MAMEHA (V.O.)(cont’d) There's a reason Hatsumomo wants you there. I. know the Baron well, Sayuri. He has a weakness for women like us...and he doesn't take refusal lightly!
The Limousine pulls up to the Baron‘s impressive GATES. Sayuri steps out, followed by Bekku.

The Baron’s spacious Japanese gardens are dominated by a magnificent old CHERRY TREE. PEACOCKS strut on the lawns. Sayuri looks for The Chairman to no avail. Mr. Bekku foll her, aloof. The Baron's WEALTHY PARTY GUESTS ~ in fashionable Western clothes - take notice of Sayuri. They crowd arourid her. Flashbulbs pop. The Chairman, strolling by himself, hears the activity an sees Sayuri, flustered, trapped by the horde. He cuts thr
Excuse me. Sayuri. Today, even the cherry blossoms are envious of her. --and escorts a grateful Sayuri to safety.
As she strolls beside the Chairman, Sayuri’s feet aren't exactly on the ground.
Something I’ve been wanting to say to you for some time now. Sayuri‘s waits with bated breath. Then: CRAIRMAN (cont’d) I‘d like to...to thank you for your attention to Nobu.  90
(hides disappointment) Oh?
Nobu can be a difficult man. So severe. Hates parties, sake only in moderation, and he disdains geisha. But...he is fond of you.
Because you admire him, I respect him more.

He would never tell you himself; he’s far too modest. We were fighting in Manchuria together. There was an explosion. He protected me from the worst of it. As you might imagine, I owe him quite a debt. SAYURI nods, moved. ) CHAIRMAN (cont'd) Nobu’s taught me a great deal. Patience, for one thing. I-~in turn--have tried to teach him. You have to savor life while you can.
The lesson of the cherry blossom.

See? That is why Nobu likes you. We must not expect happiness, Sayuri. It is not something we deserve. When life goes well, it’s a sudden gift. It cannot last forever. Like this moment. A shower of cherry petals surprises the The Chairman smiles down at Sayuri as he gently removes e petal from her hair.
Ah Sayuri, there you are. The Baron is above them on another path; Bekku lurks near Jd THE BARON I have a present for you.
As the Baron leads Sayuri and Mr. Bekku deep into his Art Deco Mansion, the SERVANTS discreetly close the shoji doo behind them.

Mameha &sked me to show you my kimono collection...It’s quite venerated. My grandfather and my father collected kimono before me. A shoji door slides shut, and Mr. Bekku disappears. Sayur looks back, alarmed. Yet another shoji closes, stranding alone with the Baron in the heart of the house. THE BARON (cont'd) I’ve given a number of valuable kimono to Mameha...I like to give presents to beautiful girls. Surrounding:them, burnished gold MIRRORS. The Baron prese her with a folded kimono: THE BARON (cont‘d) It's yours. Try it on.
The Baron is too kind. I will happily try it on. With Mameha- neisan, when the Baron returns to Miyako--

Who knows when that will be? Put it on. Now. Don’t be shy. He pulls her against him and reaching behind her, jerks o the knot of her obi-jime (obi cord). Sayuri pushes away, the silken obi cord spills to the mat. THE BARON (cont‘d) Don’t worry. I am experienced in knotting obis. Untying them as well.

Please... The Baron takes her hand, forcing it against the bristles his cheek. Then he turns her palm upward, grazing it with his lips. Sayuri tries to wrest her hand away.  92 SAYURI (cont‘d) Mr. Bekku is waiting--

Bekku’s waiting for no one. He begins to unwind her obi. Sayuri sees the Chairman‘s handkerchief fall to the floor. ' She kneels and grabs it quickly. In that moment the Baron unfastens the datejime -- the waistband underneath the ob Her kimono releases in front. Sayuri gives a cry and clutches at the fabric, desperate to conceal herself. The Baron grabs her from behind, pinning her arms back. H looks at her in the mirror ahead: her kimono open, her ey closed, and her head turned away so that the curve of her neck is exposed. He nuzzles her.

Stop, please. Stop now. Undaunted, the Baron drops her outer kimono and it puddle around her. She stands--almost naked--in her underkimono. He releases that, too. Her under-kimono falls open. Shamelessly, he reaches under it. She tries to resist, bu hands scuttle across her flesh like spiders. SAYURI(CONT'D) (cont‘d) No. No... The Baron unties her final garment. With a whisper of sil he loosens the koshimaki (final layer) from around her hi Sayuri sobs, and kneels low in an effort to hide her brea The Baron kneels beside her, and coos tenderly:

Sayuri, I only want to have a look. Nothing wrong in that. Any man would do the same. As slowly as a parent might peel the cover from a sleepin child, he opes Sayuri’s underrobe. Her beautiful back...t heart-shaped curve of her naked hips...her tabi-feet peek out from beneath... Slowly he forces her to sit up, whispering, coaxing, begg her to stand naked before the glass. Sayuri turns her fac away, squeezing her eyes shut. Clenched in her fist, the Chairman‘s handkerchief.  126 127 93 As the Baron admires her body, he slips his own hand into dank crevices of his own kimono, to pleasure himself. Sayuri, weeps silently; the very portrait of both beauty humiliation. Suddenly, she turns to him. Her eyes are swimming with tears. They pierce his soul.
. t The sliding door slides open and the Baron strides out. Behind him on the floor, Sayuri lies, cast aside amidst a pile of silk. cut TO:
Auntie pulls back the door to reveal Mameha. She is dress in formal black, and austere with anger.
Sayuri enters and bows. SAYURI’S VOICE Onei-san.
I heard a message on the wind. Alone with Mameha, Sayuri stands, head bowed: MAMEHA (cont’d) So careless! (choking back furious sobs) You have ruined all our plans!
I did nothing!
Please, Sayuri, do not insult me--I know the Baron better than that--
He gave me a kimono -
You sold yourself for a kimono??  128 94
I did not sell myself! She sees--to her dismay--that Mameha is unconvinced.
Today's the day I accept bids for your mizuage! Well, what price can I hope to demand, with a finger pointed at your back?
He looked at me. That's all, onei- san. -- which only wounds Mameha more.
You will be examined at the mizuage ceremony. If you're found to be worthless -
- I am not worthless! With a sorrowful look, Mameha leaves. INT: TATAMI ROOM. & MOTHER’S ROOM-OKIYA. DAY INTO EVENING

Seen through a slight opening in the shoji: Mameha is sequestered in Mother‘s private office, managing the bids Sayuri’s mizuage. She negotiates on Mother's telephone. In the TATAMI ROOM, Auntie keeps checking the wrist-watch keeps tucked in her obi. Everyone is waiting: Sayuri, Pumpkin, Auntie too. They he the TELEPHONE ring, and the prompt click as Mameha grabs Hatsumomo saunters in eating a yellow plum.
How much longer is this going to take? Sayuri doesn’t gratify Hatsumomo with a reaction. The TELEPHONE rings again. HATSUMOMO (cont'd) Besides, who wants a plum, when someone has already had a bite?

She and Bekku exchange a covert look of triumph. Sayuri hears the shoji door slide open. Mameha steps out, and passes Mother a slip of. paper. Hatsumomo scoffs. HATSUMOMO (cont'd) What is it? Twenty yen? Thirty? Mother fixes her glasses to her nose and peers at it anxiously: ' .
This can’t be the right amount--

I trust you agree; I have won the wager. Mother gapes at Sayuri, mute. MAMEHA (cont’d) Sayuri’s made history. No mizuage has ever been sold for more. Not even mine. (a dramatic pause, and then) Fifteen thousand yen. Sayuri stares, stunned. Hatsumomo and Pumpkin are floored Bekku chokes, Auntie begins to cry.
Unbelievable.
Arigato gozaimasu, oneisan.
Of course none of it will go to Sayuri. Or to you, Mameha. This stops Mameha, short. Mother announces smugly: MOTHER (cont'd) It goes to this okiya. All fifteen thousand yen--to this estate--
I do not understand--
--which Sayuri will inherit, as my adopted daughter.
Gasps all around.
(weakly) What?
(enraged) You wouldn‘t dare-—
(flaring too) I’m entitled to do as I choose--
But you promised the okiya to Pumpkin--
(scoffing at Pumpkin) Look at her! Still a virgin maiko! Choking back sobs, Pumpkin bolts from the room. Sayuri watches after her, her glee momentarily dimmed:
Can't you adopt us both?
Quiet, Sayuri! (back to Hatsumomo) I‘m no fool. Pumpkin would only be your puppet. How long will it take before you kick us out onto the street--
But I have given you my life--
Yes! Your impudence! Your foul temper!
Who paid for the silk on your back? The rice in your bowl? The tobacco in that pipe of yours?
Don't exaggerate! You have never even had a danna--no, oh no--  97
(sensing what’s to come) Don‘t say it-- .
You chose that no-good Koichi-~-
Stop itt ‘
Sneaking through your window at all hours of the night--
Enough!
Not like a geisha--like a common prostitute!--
Quiet!
Besides, you are getting old. An icy chill descends between the two women. MOTHER (cont'd) But Sayuri... Sayuri is destined to become a legend. Simmering, Hatsumomo starts to leave.
My dear, okasan...we will see, won't we? Mother turns to her newly-adopted daughter:

Sayuri, your room is too small. Take Hatsumomo’s. This stops Hatsumomo cold in her tracks; she shoots Sayur look that says, “I'm not done with yet.” MOTHER (cont'd) From now on, your name is Nitta Sayuri.  129
MOTHER (cont'd) (to Sayuri) You may thank me. Sayuri, speechless, bows. With a flare of her kimono, Hatsumomo is gone. Mameha excuses herself to Sayuri and Mother:

I’m happy to forsake my share of * the money, on Sayuri’s behalf. As * Miyako’s most renowned geisha, she * will no doubt be a credit to us * all. * she turns to Sayuri, and says soulfully: * MAMEHA (cont'd) * May I congratulate you both. Mameha bow and leaves. Sayuri hurries after her:
Sayuri catches Mameha in the street: : *
Oneisan! (her voice choking with * gratitude) * Everything we wanted, you made happen. Thank you. She realizes Mameha is suppressing tears.
Isn‘t success sweet?
May I ask who--
Dr. Crab. From Sayuri, a sharp intake of breath.
Was Nobu disappointed? Mameha tries to keep her voice even:

’ MAMEHA Nobu did not bid. It was against his mighty principals. (beat, then painfully) Dr. Crab was opposed by The Baron. My Baron. You want to know the truth, Sayuri? {a difficult confession) He was the highest bidder. Forgive me...but I let it go to Dr. Crab. I think you understand why.  130 131
I swear to you, I am innocent -

Of course you are! Wo man would bid so much for a thing he had already taken. It is my own fault. I did not protect you. : And then Mameha brushes aside these serious thoughts in f of a more tender one:
MAMEHA (cont’d) * Celebrate this moment, Sayuri. * Tonight, the lights in the * Hanamachi all burn for you. * She bows a deeply respectful bow. Sayuri returns it.

INT. DR. CRAB‘S CLINIC & HOME. EVENING. [SPRING] 131 Under a clinical light, Dr. Crab prepares a futon with wh hospital sheets. He sets a high pillow at one end of the futon, and a low pillow next to it for himself. He smooth hospital towel across the mid-section. Sayuri is led in to the room by Dr. Crab’s elderly maid. Sayuri wears a pretty kimono robe. The maid closes the sh screen and exits. Crab opens a wooden case that contains twenty or thirty sealed vials. In each is a brown-stained wad of cotton. D Crab opens an empty vial and fastidiously prepares a squa of clean gauze. He takes up a pen and writes a label: “Sayuri.” We SEE among the vials, similarly marked: Each is labeled with a geisha’s name. Among them is a vial marked: “Mameh Dr. Crab indicates the futon and helps Sayuri lie down. H settles her head on the high pillow. He lifts her hips an slips the towel. under her. He adjusts the light, and loo the tie around her robe. He unties his own. He opens her kimono as his body moves in to obliterate he
Sayuri returns from her vigit to Dr. Crab in a rickshaw; looks resplendent in a yellow silk kimono. Its collar is a vivid white.

The shoji screens. to the tatami room are open; Sayuri en to find Mother waiting. Mother rises and comes to her; in Sayuri‘s face, 4 change: the knowledge she has entered a realm. Tenderly, Mother cradles Sayuri’s face in her hand
My daughter. You have turned the collar. You are a full geisha now. Sayuri smiles, coy but proud. She hurries up the tansu stairs to her room: INT. SAYURI'S NEW ROOM (HATSUMOMO'S OLD ROOM). NIGHT.
Hatsumomo, lounges on Sayuri’s futon with her back to the door. A single oil lamp on a low table lights the room:
What are you doing in my room? With a sardonic smile, Hatsumomo ranks: welcomes Sayuri into her own
I came to congratulate you.
Please get out. Hatsumomo laughs, and rolls over to reveal: she‘s found Sayuri’s lacquered box and is rifling through her keepsak The photo of the Chairman, the handkerchief--
why, little Chiyo! Look what I found. (MORE )

HATSUMOMO = (cont'd) (re: handkerchief) --his initials; how elegant. You‘ve been hiding this for a long time-- Hatsumomo dips the handkerchief into an oil lamp. HATSUMOMO (cont’d) The sacrifice every Geisha must make--

Don’t. Sayuri lunges for her. Hatsumomo falls against a kimono mounted on display rods. Sayuri grapples for the Chairman handkerchief. Hatsumomo skirts away and runs to HATSUMOMO ROOM (Sayuri’s old room)-— -- and tries to slam the shoji on Sayuri’s hand, but Sayu gets in. Hatsumomo stuffs the handkerchief into her kimono:

Isn’t this where you keep it? Next to your heart? Sayuri rips Hatsumomo’s kimono open. As they struggle for the handkerchief, Sayuri’s HAIR ORNAMENT falls out onto t floor; it has a long lethal- ~looking double-pronged shaf pointed tips. Both women seize on the same thought: It is weapon. Hatsumomo darts for the ornament but Sayuri snatches it u and holds it like a knife. Hatsumomo tries to wrench it f her. In a counter-move, with sumo-like agility: Sayuri releases the hair ornament to grab the handkerchief away Hatsumomo. With a cry, Hatsumomo flies at her, stabbing at Sayuri wi the lethal hair pin. Sayuri flees - -- into the corridor, where she knocks into one of severa oil lamps. It sways crazily, making bizarre shadows. Sayu ducks away. Hatsumomo yanks Sayuri back, off-balance. Sayuri twists f but stumbles and nearly falls down the tansu stairs. She catches herself. Hatsumomo swipes at her with the hair pin. Sayuri recover and runs into HER OWN ROOM, slamming the shoji. Hatsumomo stabs the fragile old rice paper, puncturing it so-- eee OF *

-- the hair pin barely misses Sayuri’s face on the other side. Sayuri recoils. Hatsumomo throws open the shoji wit a Madwoman’s strength. She runs at Sayuri -~ Sayuri deflects the blow with a pillow. Hatsumomo slashes the pillow, and buckwheat husks fly. Sayuri throws the pillow at Hastumomo’s face. Hatsumomo swipes blindly with the hairpin, hacking away at the air --
Mother brings down her bamboo stick, hard. Hatsumomo give cry of pain and grabs her wrist. The hair pin falls. Moth picks it up.
(to Hatsumomo) I should have kicked you out long ago. Hatsumomo is breathing in frantic gasps, clutching her wr her clothing torn and her hair wild.
I’ should have left long ago!
Get out!

Very well...but before I go, let me end this...my gift to all of youl! she picks up the oil lamp and throw’s it at Sayuri‘s kimo They ignite, sparking a flame. In great gulps, FIRE devours the water image on one of Sayuri‘s kimono. Mother grabs Sayuri’s quilt and tries to smother the flam Sayuri snatches her kimono, trying to save them. Inspired now, Hatsumome bolts for the corridor and grabs another o lamp off the wall. She hurls it toward Sayuri, who ducks. The lamp crashes against a rice paper wall, and ignites i Pumpkin rushes up the tansu stairs. Hatsumomo cracks an o lamp against the wall, showering glass on Pumpkin. Shaken Pumpkin retreats down the stairs. In the KIMONO ROOM, Auntie desperately grabs red lacquere boxes. Pumpkin rushes to her aid.  5 Upstairs,
the okiya starts to scorch and cinder. Hatsumomo sinks down amongst the flames, which are as angry as the in her eyes. cur TO:  135 136 137

Aftermath and a red sky. “In the quiet dawn, Hatsumomo wa away, bereft of everything, even her household possession She turns back to stare at the okiya a final time, her fa smeared with ash. | : * The second floor is blackened by fire, but the house stil stands. Through the skeletal frame of a shoji screen wind Sayuri watches as Hatsumomo turns, vanishing into the mis From above, the MENACING ROAR of AIRPLANES. A FORMATION O ALLIED BOMBERS flies low over the torii gate, their * Bilhovuettes terrifying against the reddish sky. * Suddenly, the LURCHING ROAR of MILITARY TRUCKS--

--TRUCK WHEELS turn as JAPANESE MILITARY TRUCKS cross the bridge into the Hanamachi. JAPANESE SOLDIERS unload and disperse, begin pounding on doors of okiyas. A TRUCK fitt with a loudspeaker cruises by:
“This sector is to be evacuated, everyone mist leave. - This district is closed by official order. Please cooperate...”

The teahouse lanterns are extinguished. Theatre posters p on the long wall where GEISHA huddle in clusters, belongi heaped around them. SOLDIERS patrol as the geisha wait. MILITARY TRUCKS arrive. SOLDIERS herd a group of frighten geisha into the back compartment. They toss aside the geishas‘ belongings - not enough room in the truck. KORIN fights to be allowed onto the truck. Chairman steps down from a truck and pays the Soldier -- has bribed his way into the Hanamachi. Chairman strides off, followed at a respectful distance by an ELDERLY SERV Chairman walks past GEISHA huddied on the ground, wrapped quilts and finery. Some geisha cook over tiny fires. OTHERS sell their finery to each other. Money changes han Chairman keeps searching.  d)
The SOUND OF MORE BOMBERS passing overhead. Sayuri, consoling Mameha, looks up to see the Chairman striding toward them. Mameha gives a relieved cry:  104
Chairman! They are sending us away, but they won‘t say where--

Osaka, to work in the factories. But you must not go. The city is a prime target; they have already bombed the train station. Get your things, quickly. Sayuri & Mameha take their bundles. Sayuri grabs her shamisen. The Chairman leads them toward rickshaws: CHAIRMAN (cont’d) Nobu and I are trying to find safe havens for as many of you as we can. Here — He passes Mameha to a DRIVER and hands her a certificate CHAIRMAN (cont‘d) - Work certificate. Nurse's aid in Wadayama. Best I could do. Friend of mine is Chief Surgeon there. Hurry! (to RICKSHAW DRIVER) Take care of her. The Rickshaw Driver assists Mameha into his rickshaw. Mam realizes that she and Sayuri are to be separated:
Sayuri-chan! I will write to you!
Oneisan! Chairman has handed Sayuri’s bundle to the Elderly Servan
This is Arima; he will take you into the hills. Nobu has got a friend there; a kimono-maker. He is sewing parachutes now. (gives her certificate) Anyone stops you, show them this.
Do I have to go?
It’s remote, you will be safe---  138 139 140 141 142
What about you? You said Osaka was dangerous---

Our factory's there. I have no choice. (then) : I will express your gratitude to Nebu-san. Her gaze is locked on his as her rickshaw pulis away. SAYURI‘S VOICE Because I had endured starvation and hard work before, I knew I could survive.
