head_text.subj: EXT. RURAL RIVER. MIYARO HILLS. 1945. DAY
THE OMINOUS REFLECTION OF AIRPLANES IN DARK WATER

text: The water ripples in their trembling wake. SAYURI'S VOICE {CONT‘D) But for what purpose? The war was so devastating, so brutal. We weren’t merely defeated...we were destroyed. Whole cities evaporating in clouds of smoke.

An inky red liquid the color of BLOOD begins to course through the water's current, billowing in sanguine clouds SAYURI‘S VOICE (cont'd) The people I knew...after years of blood-shed, what terrible fates had befallen them? We follow the bloodish liquid down its watery path...wher will it take us? Toward some terrible carnage? SAYURI‘S VOICE (cont'd) Most of all, the Chairman. Now, we see the source of the tincture: long bolts of clo newly dyed, unfurled in the water like floating banners. SAYURI'S VOICE (cont‘d) Was he even alive? And if s50...would he even remember? I thought of my old life as a geisha in the Hanamachi. It felt as remote--as hazy--as a dream. Standing knee-deep in a river, her clothing rolled to her waist, a PEASANT WOMAN: we barely recognize that it’s Say The Kimono maker ARASHINO (middle-aged, weathered, kind) oversees as she and a host of OTHER WORKERS rinse their textiles.
When you’ve finished, you can string it up to dry, along with the others. Sayuri raises her hands from the stream; her skin is stai with dye.
Near the RIVER: Tail bamboo poles suspend billowing “pray flags" of drying kimono fabric. Among OTHER WORKERS, Sayu hangs the fabric. A YOUTH hurries to her, calling -

Sayuri. A man from Osaka has come te see you. Sayuri drops her work and pushes through the wilderness o fluttering silk panels. As she hastens, she pulls a peasant’s scarf off and tries to neaten her hair. id +e 143

Her heart in her throat, Sayuri sees a man in a fedora ma his way toward her through the luminescent banners of sil She believes for a moment it is the Chairman. The silk lifts, and her heart falls: The man is Nobu.
Nobu and Sayuri wander among the siik banners:
General Tottori was captured, and tried ad a war’ criminal. The Baron lost his fortune and committed suicide-—
What about the okiya?
Mr. Bekku is gone, but the others--
Auntie and Mother?
(with a smile) --indestructible as always. Sayuri summmons the courage to ask the foremost question hex mind.
And the Chairman?
As well as can be expected. From his pocket, Nobu takes a tiny shard of concrete rubb NOBU (cont'd) This is all that remains of our factories. She touches him tenderly.
I am so sorry, Nobu-san.
Sayuri, We want to rebuild. But to * do that, we will need your help.
What can I do?
Somewhere under those rags...are you still the greatest geisha in Miyako? ° Sayuri hides her stained hands,
{with a rueful laugh) If a tree has no leaves or branches, can you still call it a tree?

With nothing but rubble at my feet, can I still call myself a business man? 108 He takes her work-worn hand in his, noticing its roughene and patchy stains. NOBU (cont'd) I should have taken better care of you.
Please. You saved my life. I owe you so much in return. : He gives her hand an affectionate squeeze.

The Chairman and I need American financing. There's a man-~a . certain Colonel] Derricks--who has the power to grant us a contract. I showed him your picture. He requested to meet you. ee eR  o>~ Ww 145

He looks at her, imploringly. * NOBU (cont ’d)} I am not a persuasive man, Sayuri. But...if you and a few geisha would * once again put on your kimono and join us--we could show the * Anhericans how hospitable our * country can be-- *
(with longing) How I wish, Nobu-san! But -that was a long time ago.

I have no doubt, Sayuri, that you could still melt the heart of any man, ho matter how resistant. This slightly bald confession gives Sayuri pause; she doe want to encourage Nobu. NOBU (cont'd) I am not accustomed to begging. But please know that--if you consent--the Chairman and I would be most grateful. Just his name exerts its inexorable pull. SAYURI’s torn. What should she do?

Dressed in peasant work trousers, her hair in a long tail carrying a very small bundle, Sayuri crosses the bridge i the Hanamachi, past the Shinto shrine. She is stunned to a world utterly transformed and corrupted:  146 147 110 On the main street, SOUVENIR SHOPS selling tea sets and c cotton kimono: “KIMONO $$20$$". AMERICAN flags are plaste everywhere; American JEEPS clog the streets. A RESTAURANT touts “HAM BURGER”. At a shop, WOMEN stamp a “geisha face on scores of identical plaster dolls in paper kimono. Clusters of AMERICAN G.I.s in “civvies” weave down the st - they are drunk in broad daylight. The G.I.s shout at Sayuri, overly-friendly: DRUNKEN G.I. Hey, Mama-san! Where ya going? etc Sayuri evades by ducking into an alley. She emerges at:

AMERICAN G.I.s stand in a long queue, watched by MPs unde signs: “1 CHIT PER G.I.” “YOU MUST ACCEPT THE GIRL YOU AR ASSIGNED.” At the entry, Sayuri sees: JAPANESE PROSTITUTES in cheap kimono greet the G.I.s. MAMEHA’S VOICE Tell Nobu there are so few genuine geisha left in Miyako! INT: MAMEHA’S APARTMENT. DAY. [AUTUMN] 147 Mameha’s place is run-down; divided by makeshift curtains into small rooms. Mameha is elegant even in a cotton kimo with a frayed white collar; but she has a shattered quali now; a fragility Sayuri has not seen before.
Only “geesha girls"! Every hooker with a painted face and a silk kimono says she’s one of us! No one can tell the difference anymore!
All the more reason for us to oblige him--
Why?
To show them the truth of who we are--not the common women they believe us to be--  111

Sayuri...when my poor Baron filled his pockets with stone...I was desperate. What could I do? I sold my kimono. I traded my jade combs for rations. It was painful at first, but I have made my peace. A FEMALE BOARDER carries' HER BABY through the room, en r to the street. When she’s out of ear-shot, Mameha continu MAMEHA (cont'd) Now I make a small but tidy living, renting rooms. I am not about to start chasing the past--
It might do you good.
How?
To remind you that--once with a single glance--you could bring a man like the Baron to his knees. Mameha‘s conviction falters. She’s tempted now.

Well...I did keep one kimono. Sayuri looks up, hopeful. Mameha rummages among her thing and takes out an ornate kimono box: MAMEHA (cont'd) The Baron gave it to me, when he became my danna. They reverently caress the fabrics: Gorgeous relics of a now lost. Saruyi‘s eyes brim with gratitude.
Thank-you, O-neisan.
So tell me. What do we know about entertaining Americans?
Across JAPANESE POSTERS are plastered U.S.O. canteen announcements and G.I. graffiti: “KILROY WAS HERE”.

Bare-chested AMERICAN G.I.s in boxer shorts and dog-tags spill out of a tea room, laughing. Drunken SERVICE MEN clumsily dance with fans to a RECORD PLAYER’s American pop music. One GI strums a shamisen as it were a guitar. PUMPKIN, in a garish kimono with dog ta around her neck and an officer's cap on her head, “teache them, laughing and flirting and smoking a cigarette betwe her teeth. A G.I. kisses Pumpkin on the mouth. Pumpkin sees a peasan girl watching from the corridor: The peasant girl is Sayuri.
(with a squeal) Chiyo? Hey, Chiyo-chan! Is that you?

Broken-hearted Japanese music whines. Wedged at a tiny noodle bar, Pumpkin slurps her soup and smokes at the sam time. STEAM rises from pots, half-obscuring PEOPLE waitin behind them: WORKING CLASS JAPANESE and a few AMERICAN GI
I have no right to ask favors of you, Pumpkin. I know that-- PUMPKIN ignores Sayuri‘s remark, and says blithely:
Guess what? I only smoke Chesterfields now.
I have wanted to apologize to you for so long-- about the okiya--  113
(still ignoring her) These soldier-boys, you know who they've got me singing--
--it should have gone to you, not me-- ! ‘
--Frank Sinatra, and Dinah Shore--
--if it is in your heart to forgive me-~

(abruptly) Sayuri, don’t. Pumpkin looks at Sayuri. Underneath her tough demeanor, Sayuri can still see the impish spirit of her old friend. PUMPKIN (cont‘d) The honest truth? I‘d rather chew sand than go back to all that.
Then you are not angry with me? PUMPKIN exhales, blowing smoke.
Don’t worry about me, chickadee - I’ve got more clients than I can handle.
You seem so at home with these Americans.
(with a sly wink) They‘re bastards. (beat) So who‘s this Colonel? Sounds like top brass.
He has the power to approve American financing for Nobu and the Chairman.  151 152 153 154 155 114 Pumpkin slurps her soup, finishing it --
So is he willing to pay us American dollars? Cash? She locks at Sayuri expectantly, hunger in her eyes.

Western sofas and chairs dominate the room, which is stac with liquor and cigarettes, sewing machine parts, light bulbs, samurai swords, K-rations - anything that can be s on the black-market. In a haze of tobacco smoke, a WOMAN with bobbed hair talks on the telephone. The black-market is Mother.
Don’t waste my time. You think I’m a sucker? I want sixty cases Lucky Strike or I’m taking my business to Sergeant MacPhee... KIKO (9, Auntie’s new girl) runs through, carrying towels
Sayuri‘s wet hair streams down the back of her under-kimo Sayuri scrubs her hands ruthlessly in a steaming little b of bleach and water, using a hard brush.
Sayuri digs through the stacks of black market goods pile high in the kimono room. She finds a lone dusty kimono bo and opens it.

With her sewing box open on the floor, Sayuri expertly se new collar onto the frayed old kimono. INT: SAYURI’'S ROOM - OKIYA. NEXT DAY. [AUTUMN] 155 Sayuri’s hair is smoothed into a modest twist. She wears newly-repaired kimono. She stares: traces of Miyako’s mos celebrated geisha, restored. Auntie (older, thinner) ties her obi. Kiko watches. Auntie finishes:  156
See? You are yourself again.

On the tarmac, an U.S. transport PLANE idles. At the open hangar door a U.S. ARMY JEEP deposits Sayuri. She sees: The Chairman, standing alone, his back to her. Sayuri approaches, her heart pounding. The Chairman turns:
Sayuri, just look at you. It’s as if the war never happened. His face opens in a smile. Sayuri bows, overcome.
I am so glad to see that the Chairman is safe.
Please accept my apologies, asking this of you--
There is nothing I can do to return your kindness. But even as she speaks, a voice intrudes -

Sayuri! Then she sees: The Chairman is with Nobu and Mameha (eleg in a kimono) and TWO AMERICANS - COLONEL DERRICKS (50, ca Army) is worldly, with an off-the-cuff charm that masks h baser appetites. His Lieutenant, HUTCHINS (32, West Point is considerably greener and more impressionable-- * NOBU (cont'd) * May I present Colonel Derricks. With a coy smile Sayuri bows; DERRICKS follows suit. *
Konichiwa. You're even more * stunning in person. My associate, * Lieutenant Hutchins. (to Hutchins) Sayuri is one of the Mysteries of the Orient I’ve told you about-~ *  116
A mystery that perhaps you can solve. Hutchins holds up a camera:
Would you mind? Sayuri’s eyes meet the Chairman's briefly. He smiles, sympathetic. The Colonel offers Sayuri his arm and a suav smile; she accepts both. Together, they pose.

A perfect souvenir. She smiles, demurely. The camera flashes. PUMPKIN’S VOICE Who likes whiskey?? An Army Jeep has pulled up. Pumpkin jumps down with a hap squeal, wearing a colorful kimono and waving a bottle of Scotch. For her, the party’s already started.
Chairman, don’t tell me you started the party without me. The propeller breeze lifts Pumpkin‘s skirts and Pumpkin g a happy shriek.
(under his breath to Derricks) She's a live wire...
May I present - Pumpkin. The Lieutenant snaps a picture, to Pumpkin‘’s apparent delight. Mameha and Sayuri exchange a look, mortified for her.
Gentlemen? Nobu ushers them across the tarmac, Pumpkin pretending to pull the Chairman by the necktie, and Derricks escorting Sayuri.
In the cramped fuselage, the whir of the engines is deafening. Derricks flips down benches, and proffers seat to Sayuri:
Please, 'be my ‘guest-- Sayuri can't hear a word,, and looks at him helplessly. DERRICKS (cont'd) {again, above the roar)

Sayuri glances toward the Chairman, hoping to sit close t him. But Pumpkin has already claimed him, pulling him dow on the opposite bench. Mameha sits on his other side. And Hutchins--his Adams apple bobbing in his throat--sidles d next to Pumpkin, clearly smitten. What can Sayuri do but respond:

(to Derricks) Thank you, I am most grateful-- He tugs on his ear; what? SAYURI (cont'd) --PERFECT. YES. Dispirited, Sayuri sinks down to find herself cramped bet Derricks and Nobu. In the din, talk is futile. The Colone smiles at her, and she offers a coquettish glance. But sh can’t help staring at the Chairman longingly, as he, Mame and Pumpkin all dissolve into giggles over a joke she can hear.

location: TAKAMAYA HOT SPRINGS RESORT. LATE DAY.

text: Sayuri-~in a robe--pads through the women’s dressing area route to the natural, lagoon-like hot spring. She hears VOICES and LAUGHTER. Sayuri takes off her robe behind the wall of the dressing area, and modestly slips into the spa waters.
Don’t be shy, gentlemen!

\ ) Pumpkin gestures to the men to come and join the ladi and Mameha are already relaxing in the pools. Derricks, Hutchins, Nobu and the Chairman slide over to them. By Japanese custom, everyone is naked. A wooden tray floats, holding bottles of sake.
Back home, a bath is nothing but a ‘ quick shower on cold tile with a bar of lye soap--
(with an expansive sigh) Ah, but here, you make everything a ritual, don’t you?
That is the art of turning habit into pleasure, Colonel.
Said like a true geisha! Nobu nods, but his face betrays a slight wince.
If we are in business together, then perhaps we will visit you some day. I‘d love to see the United States.
Why, sure. We could teach you some of our customs. Like forks and proper chairs and what it feels like to sleep on a real mattress-—— Pumpkin bulldozes in:
(already drunk) I know a little game we can play. It's called “Truth and Lies.”
I know that game, too. Back home, they call it “marriage.” Hearty male laughter all around.
(giggling) . No! I‘m serious. Now listen closely. Sayuri knows the rules--
I never met a woman who didn’t! More laughter, louder from the Americans than the Japanes
(acquiescing) Each person says two things. One is true; the other is not.

If you guess right, the liar pays the price. - demonstrating the price: A big swallow of sake right fr the bottle. The men laugh. ” DERRICKS So it pays to lose! Laughter, louder from the Americans than the Japanese. Pumpkin tries to think of a story -
I go first! Now let me see...One day in Sapporo, where I was born, a fisherman caught a talking fish. Trouble is, it only spoke Russian--
~ The other story is the true one, and I have not even heard it yet! Everyone laughs. Pumpkin pushes the Chairman, flirting:

If I drown, it’s all your fault. -- taking a big swallow of sake. She tips backward in the water and Chairman has to catch her. Sayuri and Mameha exchange a look: Pumpkin’s behavior is crossing the line.
Your turn, Nobu-san.
(declining to play) I am no match for these geisha; (MORE )
120 NOBU (cont'd) they are experts in the art of deceit.
Sayuri, maybe. I’m an expert in one thing and one thing only: sake! Chairman floats the tray of sake over to Sayuri:
Sayuri. The truest story you know. All eyes are on Sayuri. She gathers her courage. When she starts to speak, the timbre in the room changes; from rau to almost reverential.

Once when I was a little girl...on the banks of the Sonogawa...a handsome stranger gave me a cup of ice--ice that tasted as sweet as a mid-summer plum-- The Chairman and Mameha exchange a look. In Mameha’s eyes an implicit challenge to the Chairman: will you or will y not acknowledge the truth of Sayuri's story? The Chairman about to blush; then he interrupts:
I think we have to stop the game. PUMPKIN giggles, very drunk. CHAIRMAN (cont‘d) If Pumpkin drinks any more sake, she will pass out.
Now that - is a true story. Everyone laughs. Sayuri looks at the Chairman, crestfalie

Here - Mameha - Sayuri - help her. And the party starts to break up. Mameha helps the limp Pumpkin out of the pool and into her bathing kimono. As Sayuri starts to climb out of the water, Derricks corners her:
So...ah...what’s the protocol?  159
Excuse me?
Suppose I wanted to see you. In private. Sayuri watches as the Chairman gently guides a hapless Pumpkin toward the dressing rooms; Pumpkin rests her head his shoulder.
I beg your pardon, Colonel; that is not a geisha‘’s custom--
If it’s a question of price--
If there were a price, you could never afford it-- Nobu looks on, jealous, even as Sayuri rebukes the Colone darting under his arm and getting away --
Wait--now just a‘ minute--
Nobu turns angrily on Sayuri -- : *
I saw the two of you whispering-- you have arranged some kind of tryst, haven't you—— Sayuri matches his rage with her own:
What did you promise him? Glaring at her, he pours himself a glass of whiskey.
Your company! Nothing more!
Be seemed to expect a great deal--!
If I had wanted a common whore, I could have hired one---
What are you trying to say--

Just the idea of you with him--with any man--you would be dead to ne, Sayuri--- Nobu siams his glass on the table so hard it shatters. NOBU (cont’d) Can't you see that I want you for myself? Be opens his hand. In it, shards of glass. Blood creases his palm. Sayuri grabs a cloth but Nobu waves her off angrily -- NOBU {cont‘d) You have ruined me. Before we met, I was a disciplined man. He does not let her assist as he wraps his hand with clot NOBU (cont'd) I should not have asked you to come. The Chairman was against it; I should have listened to him. SAYURI stares at the floor, and says quietly:
(staring down) I must beg your forgiveness, Nobu- san. I was foolish to think you would barter me away.
Then you made no arrangement with the Colonel--
Please. Don’t insult me again. NOBU looks up at her, his eyes rimmed in red.  160 161
If he ratifies our contract, then T will be a man of means again. There is nothing I want more, Sayuri..-than to become your danna.
(blanching) I already owe you far too much--
1 will not be refused!
Please--
--we are tied to each other, I know you feel it too-- I never
meant to mislead you--

(evenly, but with force) Sayuri. I do not like things held up before me that I cannot have. EXT. WOMEN’S TATAMI ROOM. RESORT. NIGHT. [AUTUMN } Distraught, Sayur 4 hurries up the path to Mameha's room. INT. WOMEN’S TATAMI ROOM. RESORT. NIGHT. [AUTUMN } Sayuri pleads with Mameha.
When you first introduced me to Nobu-~I was such a fool to give him my attention-
Nonsense-—- 160 161
I never meant to make him care--
(shecked) You cannot refuse him. You must not!
But Mameha why?
What is he to think? He safeguarded your life--
And so he owns it?
Sayuri. I know what's it like to try and scrape by without a danna--
--I'll do something~-anything else-- MAMEHA. _-renting rooms, scrounging for every meal--is this the life that you want?
--I want a life that is mine--
Nobu has never treated you with anything but kindness--
zr don't want mere kindness!
What more can we expect? 124  162
You had feelings for the Baron, didn't you? -
_ (beat) t never ‘allowed myself that.
Don’t lie to me.
In time, you learn--
--I don't want to learn--
Sayuri! We don’t become geisha to pursue our own destinies! (harshly) We become geisha because we have no choice. on Sayuri’s trapped expression ~- cur TO:
Pumpkin, dressed, is going to dinner when a frantic Sayur stops her on the path:
Pumpkin?
What is it? What's wrong?
Nothing. I have a favor to ask, that's all.
Ask. Before speaking, Sayuri glances nervously to her left and right to ensure that the coast is clear.
At nine o’clock--bring Nobu to the pooi, on the far side of the garden-  Al63 163 164 165
Pumpkin lifts a savvy brow. SAYURI (cont‘d) Not a minute before, not a minute after, yes? And--please--do not tell him that I will be there, waiting——
It's a surprise? Sayuri notes Derricks smoking on a distant terrace.
(with gravity) Yes. It’s a surprise. Pumpkin watches Sayuri walk away; her expression is unreadable. ©
Sayuri finds the Colonel, smoking. Privately, they confer We don’t hear a word.

From a slight distance: Derricks, Hutchins, Nobu and the Chairman sit down for dinner. All of the men wear kimono. Mameha pours sake. ‘TWO GEISHA serve dinner. Derricks, checking his watch, swallows his drink and discreetly excuses himself from the group.

location: ON THE PATH TO THE PRIVATE POOL. NIGHT., (AUTUMN)

text: As Derricks walk down the path, he looks to see if anyone following. He checks his watch; it’s five minutes until nine.
From a slight distance: Pumpkin enters the pavilion where men are seated. Pumpkin kneels between Nobu and the Chaiz and begs their pardon for interrupting them. 163 163 164

Sayuri waits, nervously. She glances at her own watch. Sh hears the shojii screens slide open, and the Colonel ente She buries her watch in her clothing, then rushes to gree the Colonel. She silently ushers him inside. +t OF Sayuri slides shut the privacy door. The rustic wooden hu is dimly lit by lanterns; hazy steam rises from a rectang pool. Sayuri efficiently unknots Derricks’s obi. With trembling fingers, she jerks the knot of her kimono sash.
Please. Allow me. He picks at the knot slowly as she watches with barely hi impatience. She glances at his watch and grabs the knot, unties it herself. DERRICKS (cont'd) The pool?

Bere. Sayuri hastily arranges herself on the wooden platform be the hot pool. She opens her kimono slightly. Derricks kneels over her. Sayuri glances at his watch. Where jis Pumpkin? SAYURI (cont ’d) Wait. Derricks senses her sudden nervousness and hesitates:

Are we doing this or not? She neds, eyes on his watch: The face has misted, but she see -~ it ticks forward from 9 o'clock. Derricks starts t kiss her. To buy time, Sayuri twists away. DERRICKS {corit’d) You don’t kiss? Again he tries to kiss her. Again she turns her face away DERRICKS (cont'd) Come on now. Don't be shy. T know you people kiss--
Pinally he opens his kimono, and rolls on top of her, cradling her face in his hands.  2. 168 169
Two feminine feet, padding down the walk-way at a clip, followed by two male ones.

The Colonel, on top of Sayuri, pins her arms to the groun Sayuri lets out a sound somewhere between a gasp and a so The pavilion door slides open, and Pumpkin steps in. Sayuri and the American turn and see Pumpkin. Then behind Pumpkin comes -- The Chairman. Chairman recoils, shocked. Sayuri pushes the Colonel away grabs her kimono to herself. The Chairman quickly steps out. Sayuri, dressing hastily, rushes past Pumpkin and out the door, and sees -

location: PATH TO THE PRIVATE POOL. NIGHT.

text: The Chairman walks away quickly in the moonlight. Sayuri whirls on Pumpkin who has followed her out:
How could you? You don’t know what you have done! Pumpkin‘s expression morphs; suddenly, she has the same hauteur--the same cruel calm--as her teacher Hatsumomo,.
But I do.
I do not understand; Why did you * have to bring the Chairman?
Because I know how you feel about him. (MORE )
-so Hatsumomo did teach you to be cruel-- Pumpkin's mouth stretches into a tight, joyless smile.
A long tite ago you took something from me...the only thing I'd ever truly wanted. (beat) Well. Now you know how it feels. In Sayuri's face, the sting of betrayal.

location: CLIFFS AND THE SEA. DAWN. WIND.

text: Alone, Sayuri walks in the wind and spray. She has never felt more alone, more degraded.
To a new partnership, gentlemen.

head_text.subj: EXT. TAKAMAYA RESORT ENTRANCE GATE. DAWN.

text: The Chairman and Nobu smile graciously, bidding the Ameri farewell.
I like the way you people do business. Sealing it with a kiss. They start climbing aboard their jeep to depart.

location: CLIFFS AND THE SEA. DAWN. WIND.

text: Sayuri lets the tears come, wiping them away with the Chairman’s handkerchief.

head_text.subj: EXT. TAKAMAYA RESORT ENTRANCE GATE. DAWN.

text: The jeep revs its motor, and Derricks winks at Nobu, man- man:
Give my regards to Sayuri now, won't you? 170 171 172 173
{ ) As the vehicle pulls away, Nobu feel as if he‘s been in the face. He covers, clenching the muscles in his jaw.  174 175 2 176

location: CLIFFS AND THE SEA. DAWN. WIND.

text: The wind rises. Sayuri raises her hand, and lets the handkerchief go. The wind seizes it and carries it away; with it, everything Sayuri has ever known. EXT. HANAMACHI STREETS. ANOTHER DAY. [AUTUMN]. A scorching red sun rises over Miyako, like a crimson hal the sky. INT. THE OKIYA. SAYURI’S ROOM. DAY [AUTUMN] Sayuri sits in darkness; the shoji screen flies open, and Mother appears, with Kiko underfoot
Sayuri! Quickly! Sayuri lifts her eyes. MOTHER (cont ‘d) The Matsushima Teahouse just called- - you are to meet a very important client tonight--
(dully} Who?

Iwamura Electric! It must be Nobu, yes? Sayuri’s jaw muscles clench, but she says nothing. Mother heads to the door and looks back with pride. MOTHER (cont ’‘d) The Americans are financing his company; he’s going to be one of the richest men in Osaka! Surely he wants to honor his promise...to become your danna at last! Mother beams with pride at Sayuri. Inside, Sayuri crumble MOTHER (cont'd) It’s about time. Finally, a return on my investment. (MORE )
ee
MOTHER (cont’d) (to Kiko) Perhaps one day, you will be as lucky! Sayuri looks at Kiko sadly, then says almost to herself:
No geisha can ever hope for more.
SAYURI (cont'd)

Sayuri makes her way across the pridge to the teahouse. H face has become as frozen, as perfect as 4 mask. The TEAHOUSE MISTRESS ushers Sayuri into the garden. . Japanese maple trees frame a small pond. In its center, 4 floating platform, accessible by a series of stone steps. it, a low table with a sake tray. In her long kimono, Sayuri almost seems to walk across the water until she reaches the tiny 4sland. She kneels, waiting for Nobu to arrive. Sayuri is distracted by 4 gust of autumn wind, which send red maple leaves scattering across the watex. She feels a hand alight on her shoulder; she looks up to greet Nobu. Instead, she sees the Chairman. *
Chairman, where is Nobu-san? *
(calmly) He won't be coming tonight. * SAYURI looks stricken.
(with alarm) Is something wrong? *
Be knows what happened. It is not * in his nature to forgive. Sayuri feels a aick rush of shame; she cannot meet his ey
Chairman, what happened on the island ~-
Please. You do not have to explain- _The look in your eyes was 5° * desperate--like you might drown-~ *
But I have shamed myself so deeply, past all forgiveness~-~—
No I am the one who must be forgiven.
Sayuri bows, hex lashes wet with tears:
I do not understand.
perhaps;-if you had only known the truth-- ,
The truth? Now it’s the Chairman who's anxious, hopeful that Sayuri won't condemn him.

some years ago, I was on my way to the theater. I saw 4 little girl, weeping by the Scnogawa. IT stopped to buy her a cup of sweet ice-- SAYURI raises her head to look him in the face. Her eyes. wide with incredulity.
you knew I was that little girl? The Chairman nods.
Didn't you ever wonder why Mameha, took you her under her wing.
{the truth dawning) Mameha came to me because of you. The Chairman nods again. SAYURI (cont'd) I wish you could have told me long ago--
What could I do? I owe Nobu my jife. And so--when I saw he had a chance at happiness with you--I stood silent. But I cannot any longer. (beat) I hope it is not too late. Sayuri bows her head.
CHAIRMAN (cont' d) pon‘t be afraid to look at me chiyo.
He gently raises her face to meet his gaze; she is crying Passion, then insecure hope.

Can't you see? Every step I have taken since I was that child on the bridge has been to bring myself closer to you.: The Chairman kisses her tears. Then he kisses her; her fi kiss, tender and true. Sayuri's heart is soaring, liberat at last. SAYURI‘S VOICE I cannot tell you what guides us in this imperfect life. The Chairman and Sayuri walk along the water's edge in th teahouse garden; we see them reflected in the pond’s surf SAYURI‘S VOICE (cont‘d) But when I look back, I see myself, falling toward the Chairman as surely as a stone must fall toward the earth. Red leaves from the maple tree fall onto the pond, and gl over its surface, disrupting the reflection of the two lovers.
Hk

SAYURI'S VOICE (cont‘d) Our world is no more permanent than a wave that rises on the ocean. The ripples in the water clarify: Sayuri walks alone by t water, dressed in Western clothes now, smartly tailored. hair is cut fashionably short--

--as she strolls by a pond in a different park. She pause by the water’s edge. SAYURI’S VOICE (CONT‘D) The people we have known, even the earth beneath our feet, can all disappear in the tide. A small boy (4), runs to her as a flock of pigeons disper with a flurry. SAYURI'S VOICE (cont'd) There's only one way to anchor them- safely--in our hearts: to tell their stories. The child grabs her hand and pulls her. SAYURI'S VOICE (cont'd) The Chairman left this world a while ago... Together they stroll toward the street. SAYURI‘'S VOICE (cont'd) ++-and yet, I have him still. They turn a corner--

head_text.subj: EXT. FIFTH AVENUE. NEW YORK CITY. DUSK.

text: ---and we recognize the place; we're in 1950‘s New York. It's Fifth Avenue at rush hour. Businessmen step out of office buildings; secretaries skirt by bustling delivery in bikes. Policeman on horseback. Mother and son are swep up in the rolling sea of people. SAYURI‘S VOICE For I have lived my life again, telling it to you.
Like some vast current, the crowd carries them along unti at last--they vanish. : FADE OUT.
